MARY ANN INGRAM . I am the wife of George Ingram, a printer, living in Middle-street, Smithfield. On Friday last I went to the station, and saw a copper, which I had missed on the Tuesday before—it was fitted in the kitchen, when it was safe—I lost some books, a gown, a petticoat, and some letters—i found them in the copper—Mrs. Caffrey had left them in my care—my landlord is John Lucas Marks.

ISABELLA CAFFREY . I am the wife of a soldier, and live in Bird-court, London-wall. In consequence of information I went with ingram to the station—I saw the books, a gown, and three letters—they are mine—i had left them in charge of Mrs. Ingram about a fortnight before.

Prisoner's Defence. I met a shipmate in the Strand; he gave me some beer; I turned up short's-gardens; he wished me to carry this for him, which I did; the policeman came up to me; I turned, and the person was making his escape; I thought it was advisable for me to do so.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Six Months.

1067.
HARRIET BIRD was indicted
for stealing, on the 20th of Ja
nuary, 2 sheets, value 4s.; 2 blankets, value 8s.; 1 bed-tick, value 6s.; candlestick, value 1s.; 1 tea-kettle, value 1s.; and 1 coffee-not, value 1s.; the goods of
Maria Mann.

MARIA MANN . I formerly lived in Turnmill-street, Clerkenwell—while I was living there the prisoner had a furnished lodging of me—she had a female companion—they quitted on the 20th of January, without giving at any notice, in the middle of the night—I afterwards missed these things from their room—this sheet is mine.

RICHARD HENRY CLOUD . I am in the service of Mr. Fleming, a pawn
broker, in Farringdon-street. This sheet was pledged, I believe, by the prisoner on the 22nd of February, for 1s. 6d.—this is the duplicate I gave for it.

CHARLES ELLIOTT (police-constable G 132.) I took the prisoner as Monday last—she was taken to the station, and searched—I after wards received a duplicate from the searcher—I returned it to the searcher again.
MARY ANN REDMAN . I am searcher at the Clerkenwell station, I searched the prisoner, and found on her the duplicate of the sheet.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 17.—
Confined Three Months.

1068.
CHARLES CARTWRIGHT and
CHARLES CONNOLLY were indicted for
breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Crane on the 22nd of February, at Hendon, and stealing therein, 4 gowns, value 1l. 10s.; 1 gown-skirt, value 1s.; 2 waistcoats, value 1s.; 1 pettcoat, value 1s.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 6s.; 1 jacket, value 3s.; 3shawls, value 15s.; 1 coat, value 3s.; 1 tobacco-box, value 9d.; 3lbs. weight of pork, value 1s.; 6lbs. weight of beef, value 1s. 6d.; and 3lbs. weight of bread, value 6d.; the goods of
John Crane; and that Cartwright had been before convicted of felony.

MARY CRANE . I am the wife of John Crane, and live at Child's-hill, in the parish of Hendon—I sleep there. I left home at eight o'clock, on the morning of the 22nd of February—I left the house fastened up—I was sent for about one—the front door was then broken open, the box in the bed-room broken open, and all the things stated gone—they were safe when I left home—here are what I lost.

HENRY NORTH . I am a labourer, living in Child's Hill-lane, near Crane's. At five minutes past twelve o'clock, on the 22nd of February, I was going to dinner—I saw the two prisoners coming down the lane, about half-a-mile from Crane's—they were going in the direction of Crane's, and as was sitting having my dinner, I saw them cross the field, and Cartwright had a bundle—I sent a little boy to give information—I then went down myself, and found Crane's house open—I went in pursuit of the prisoners—they saw me, and Cartwright dropped the bundle—I still followed, and got two fields further—I then picked up another bundle—I do not know who dropped it—I took them up—they contained these articles, which the prosecutrix identifies—I followed the prisoners to Bell's Eyes, Park-bridge, then to Chalk Farm public-house, then to the Southampton Arms, then to the George at Hampstead, and there we met them coming along—I am sore they are the two men who were together when the bundle said I was mistaken, it was not him, he was at Westminster at the time.

JOHN CRANE , junior. I received information, and went after the pri
soners—I saw Connolly with a handkerchief—he hallooed out to me, "If you see ever an old b—r following after us, tell him you have not seen us"—I followed him, and as he was going into Bell's Eyes-field he dropped the bundle which had the meat—we followed the prisoners towards Chalk Farm, and at last came up with them.

RICHARD NEILD (police-sergeant S 3.) I took Cartwright—I said I wanted him for that job at Child's-hill—he said, "You are always want
ing me for something"—he said, "It was not me, I have just come from Westminster."
WILLIAM SIMMONDS (police-constable S 97.) I went to Mr. Hilton, a baker, at West-end—I got the bundle which North left there.

JAMES THOMAS (police-constable S 53.) I went in search of Connolly—I met him at Highgate—he ran off—I pursued, and called "Stop thief"—I took him when he had run a mile or more—I said I wanted him for breaking into Crane's house at Child's-hill—he said it was not him, it was Cartwright—I searched him—he had part of a loaf and 3 1/2 d.—on the way he asked what they would do to him—I said the Jury must tell him—he said he supposed it would be a tenner.

Cartwright's Defence. I met this prisoner, and asked him to go with me to Westminster, to enlist for a soldier; we went, and he was not tall enough; as they would not take him, I would not go; we went back to Hampstead, and then they took us.
RICHARD NIELD . I produce a certificate of the prisoner Cartwright's former conviction, which I got from the Clerk of the Peace of St. Albans—(read)—I know he is the person named in it.

CARTWRIGHT—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

CONNOLLY—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Ten Years.

1069.
WILLIAM TOWNSEND was indicted
for breaking and enter
ing the dwelling-house of
George Toms, on the 28th of January, at St. Dunstan, Stepney, and stealing therein 1 table-cloth, value 9s., the goods of
George Toms.

ESTHER TOMS . I am the wife of George Toms, and am a laundress, and live in Gloucester-street. I work for Dr. Bennett, in the Commercial. road—I had a table-cloth hanging on a line in the parlour-some one knocked at the door, and told me something—I ran into the parlour, and the table-cloth was gone—I had seen it safe about a quarter of an hour before, when I had shut the window—I dwell in the house—it is in the parish of St. Dunstan, Stepney.

MARTEN WELBROCK . I live with my father, in Gloucester-street, Com
mercial-road. At half-past nine o'clock on this morning, I was going along Gloucester-street—I saw the prisoner come to the prosecutor's window, and lift it up—he walked as far as the Bricklayers' Arms public-house—he then came back, and went to push the blinds open, but I suppose be saw some one—he went by, and came back again, pushed open the blinds, pot his knee on the table, took the table-cloth, and went away—I had known him for three years by sight.
CHARLES STEEL . I have known the prisoner some time—a little after eight o'clock I saw him pass my father's house, No. 1, Gloucester-street while we were at breakfast.
Prisoner. I am innocent.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Nine Months.

1070.
JOHN THOMPSON was indicted
for obtaining goods by false pretences: to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 40.—
Confined One Month.

1071.
JOSEPH BRODERICK was indicted
for a like offence; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Three Months.

1072.
WILLIAM CLAY was indicted
for a like offence; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 12.—
Confined Three Months.

1073.
WILLIAM MATTHIAS was indicted
for assaulting
Robert Clarke, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

1074.
JAMES OAKFORD was indicted
for a misdemeanor.
NOT GUILTY .

1075.
ROBERT GOODE was indicted
for assaulting
Sophia Page, with intent, &c.

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined One Year.

1076.
JOHN MURPHY and
WILLIAM HONIFORD were indicted for
stealing, on the 10th of January, 2 bags, value 8s.; 434lbs. weight of horsehair, value 24l.; 70lbs. weight of rabbit-skins, value 3l. 10s.; and 30lbs. weight of hare-skins, value 2l.; the goods of
Samuel Tanner and another.
MR. CLARKSON declined the Prosecution.
NOT GUILTY .

1077.
FREDERICK CRAKE was indicted
for feloniously uttering, on the 22nd of February, a forged request for the delivery of 1 gallon of porter, knowing it to be forged, with intent to defraud
Thomas Dyer.

THOMAS DYER . I keep a beer-shop at Forest-gate, West Ham. I took a board with some writing in pencil on it over to Mr. Lane, of Elm Cottage, Upton-place, on Wednesday morning, the 22nd of February—I saw Mr. Lane there, and made inquiry of him respecting it—it is a regular way, in the carpentering line, to send orders written on pieces of wood like this.

CHARLOTTE DYER . I am the last witness's wife. On Tuesday, the 22nd of February, the prisoner came with a piece of board, which he pro
duced to me for a gallon of porter—I said I did not know the party—he said they were working at Elm-cottage, where the board was directed; that he was the foreman, and the gentleman who was going to occupy the house when finished, had given the foreman some money—I asked a per
son who was there at the time if he knew the persons at the building—he said yes, and he thought I should get the money—I let him have a gallon of beer upon what is written on this board—(read)—"Please, Mr. Dyer, let the bearer have one gallon of porter for Mr. Lane, at Elm-cottage"—he afterwards fetched two more.

THOMAS LANE . I am foreman of the plasterers employed in repairing Elm-cottage. The writing on this board is not mine—I never authorized the prisoner to go to get the beer, or knew of his going, further than that on Tuesday, the 22nd, there was some beer brought into the building—I was at work in the drawing-room, and he was at work for the men in front of the house—they gave him two days' work, as he had nowhere to go to—they brought some beer into the drawing-room, and I had some, but I did not know how it was obtained till next day, when Dyer came and inquired if I had sent this board—I said no, and what fools they must be to let the beer go—it is not an ordinary mode of sending an order for beer on a board in this way—I did not desire the prisoner to go and get some beer, nor express a wish that he should go.

Prisoner. On Tuesday, the 22nd of February, I was directed by my employer, Mr. Sims, of Mile End-road, to go to Elm-cottage, to finish the job he had commenced some time previous; Lane asked me if I had any objection to fetch a gallon of porter; I said none in the least, and asked him where from, being a perfect stranger to the man and the place; he sent his plasterer's boy for a pencil and a piece of board, and wrote that order in my presence; he gave it into my hands; I read it over, and asked if that was his name; he said yes, it was all right, and directed me to the house where the beer was to be fetched from. I went to the house, and saw Mrs. Dyer; I gave her the board, and after some conversation with a footman who was there, she gave me the beer, which I took back to the building, and Lane, and all the men, except one who was a tee-totaller, drank of it. When Dyer called next morning, Lane denied having written the board; at that time I was not at work at the building, but at my master's yard; in the evening be accused me of having done this act, and discharged me; next morning I went to Elm-cottage to inquire about it; Lane gave me a breakfast, and

said he had seen Mr. Dyer, and made it all right, that he had agreed to pay him back on Saturday or Monday; consequently I stopped at the building till two o'clock; on my road home I met Mrs. Dyer, who asscused me of this and asked if I had any objection to be given in charge; I said, "Not the slightest;" a policeman was sent for, and I was taken before a Magistrate—Dyer called at Elm-cottage, to ask Lane whether he did write this board or not, and to come to the Magistrate; he said he would not go without a policeman; Dyer obtained one, and on his return found the garden-gate locked, and Lane spoke from the inside; the consequence was they were obliged to come away without him; the Magistrate directed him to be fetched to Bow next morning, but on the policeman going, he found the gate locked, and Lane said he would not come forward without a written order; one was obtained, and he was taken to Ilford on Saturday, where he stated that he did not write the order.

CHARLOTTE DYER
re-examined. When I met the prisoner, he expressed himself willing to meet the charge, and said that Lane had wished him to get another gallon.

THOMAS DYER
re-examined. I was ordered by the sergeant to go and demand Lane, and take him before the Magistrate—he said he should not go without an officer—I went and got a policeman, and then the gate was locked against us—he came to the gate, and said he would not go at all—we returned to the Magistrate, and the sergeant was ordered to go to his lodging at the Dog public-house, and warn him to appear—he was not there, but we left word with his brother—he did not appear—next morn
ing a summons was granted, and we had a hard matter to get him served with it, the gate was locked—next day we went to the Dog, where he generally takes his meals, waited till the gate was open, and then bolted in upon him—Elm-cottage was under repair at the time, and there were pieces of board like this lying about—Lane is a plasterer, but there were carpenters there—the other men said they knew nothing at all about it—the prisoner has made the same defence all along.

THOMAS LANE
re-examined. I did not ask the prisoner to fetch a gallon of porter—I can write—on my oath I did not write what is on this board—I have heard the prisoner state before this that I wrote it—I did not give him any breakfast afterwards—he was saying to the men that he had no place to go to, he did not know what to do, and he wished we would let him sleep in the building or he must walk the streets, for his master would take him up, and he would as soon be in prison as out, and then he would be sure of a night's lodging—he had no shoes to his feet, and two or three of the men said it would be better not to let him be in the building at all.

Prisoner. He himself proposed my sleeping there—the Carpenter was in the habit of sleeping in the house—he occasionally went home, and this man said the carpenter would be very glad of the opportunity of my sleep
ing there. Witness. I did not propose his sleeping in the house, for did not think the things would be safe—I was not at all backward in coming as a witness—two or three men saw him write this board—they are not here—I am quite sure I had no hand in this—I had some of the porter.

1078.
JOHN PHEILBY was indicted
for stealing, on the 2nd of February, 1 coat, value 25s.; the goods of
David Protheroe: and 1 coat, value 5s.; the goods of George Browne; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Four Months.

1079.
THOMAS HUDGELL was indicted
for obtaining 3 sovereigns, of
Ann Jones, by false pretences, on the 28th of January; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged.28.—
Confined One Year.

1080.
GEORGE THOMPSON was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of February, at Woolwich, 3 watches, value 9l.; 22 spoons, value 6l. 17s.; 1 buckle, value 1l.; 2 pair of sugar-tongs, value 1l. 10s.; 1 watch
chain, value 1l. 10s.; 1 seal, value 1l. 10s.; 2 watch-keys, value 1l.; 1 bag, value 1d.; 1 guinea, 1 crown, 8 half-crowns, 20 shillings, and 9 groats, the property of
Edward Burch, in his dwelling-house.

CHARIES BURGESS GOFF (police-constable L 31.) On Friend the 4th of February, the day that the king of Prussia was about to embark from Woolwich I was sent by the commissioners down to Woolwich in plain clothes—I was at the Bell public-house, at the Water-gate, at Woolwich, about four o'clock in the afternoon—I went up stairs in search of a person, and took hold of the handle of the first door I came to on the right hand side of the stair-case as I went up—it was closed—I observed two persons standing on the landing to the left of that door—I knew them both by sight—neither of them was the prisoner—one of them said something to me—I partly opened the door, and saw a bed to the right—I was in the act of pulling the door to again, when one of the persons made the observation to me, saying he had made a mistake—I then went into the public room directly opposite the bed-room—I merely looked round—I had to close the door after me to do so, to see who was there, as the door opened into the middle of the room—I then came out again—on again coming to the landing there were no persons standing at the bed-room door—the two men I had before seen, appeared to me to be coming into the refreshment-room—in consequence of suspicions I entertained I went and gave infor
mation to the landlord, who went up stairs—one of the men I had seen came down stairs and went out—I then heard the cry of "Thieves," and something else—I could not catch the other word—upon that I gave infor
mation to a constable outside to go into the house while I went after the person who went out—I followed the man I had seen come out, and took him into custody, also two others, but I afterwards found I was mistaken in one, and he was let go at the station-house—he was a respectable man living in Woolwich-upon the person of the man that I saw go down stairs was found a gold watch-chain, key, and some money, but having no reference to this case-after being taken before a Magistrate he was dis
charged, and the other two as well—one was permitted to go on his own recognizance.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. You were fined by Mr.

Groves for your conduct in the transaction? A. No—I was not fined, but I put some money into the poor-box at the suggestion of the Magis
trate—the person I had suspicion of did not turn out to be a highly re
spectable gentleman, the son of a county Magistrate—there were two taken up at my instigation—one was Mr. Cohen—he was discharged at the station-house—he was not charged at all—he was kept at the station three or four minutes—at the time I took hold of the bed-room door I supposed it to be the refreshment-room—it was the first room you arrive at in going up stairs—I did not see the prisoner there at all.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. You took a gentleman into custody by mistake? A. Yes, named Hurry—he turned out to be the son of a Magistrate—he went to the commissioners to complain of my having taken him into cus
tody—he left a letter there stating that if I found I was mistaken, and made an apology before the Magistrate, and put something into the poor
box, whatever Mr. Grove might think fit, he should be satisfied, and accordingly by Mr. Grove's direction I put 10s. into the poor-box.

EDWARD BURCH . I keep the Bell public-house at the Water-gate, Woolwich. On Friday afternoon, the 4th of February, about four o'clock, I received information from Goff, in consequence of which I went up stairs to my bed-room door, which is on the right-hand side, and about three steps from the top—it was open—I met the prisoner at the door, coming out of the room—I had locked the door two hours before—the plate was kept there, but the spoons in the knife-case were moved by my wife—when I last saw them safe, they were in the knife-case in the bed-room—there was a chest on a chest of drawers having eight drawers in it—the prisoner was at the door which was half open—I took hold of his collar with each hand, and called "Murder! thieves!"—my wife and servant ran up stairs and took hold of the prisoner—a man's arm then came out of the room—I did not see the man, because the door was on the jar—he came and hit me in the mouth, and tried to knock me down stairs—that was when my wife was coming upstairs before she got up—he hit me on the chin—it did not hurt me (after I had locked the bed-room door I gave the key to my wife) my wife and the servant-maid scuffled with the prisoner—one took hold of one collar, and the other of the other—I went into the bed-room and found all the things pulled off the bedstead on to the floor, bed and all, and all the drawers open but two—I missed my watches, which I had seen in the drawers that day or the day before—we had twenty-two spoons—we found five of them again—a man picked them up on the stairs and brought them to me—I missed two pairs of sugar-tongs, fifteen tea-spoons, a pair of salt
spoons, an old guinea, 2l. worth of silver, and several pieces of old coin, but I do not know what—I produced the five table-spoons before the jus
tice—the moment I got to the room-door and found the door open, I found the prisoner coming out—the drawers were all unlocked but two, and I could not lock them again with the key—they had been picked—these five spoons now produced are five of the spoons which were in my bed-room that afternoon.

Cross-examined. Q. How soon after the policeman made a communi
cation did you go up? A. Not a minute after—I asked my wife for the key, and ran up as fast as I could—the prisoner was about twelve steps from the door when I first saw him—the door was on the jar, just as the other man had let him out—the man's arm hit me on the chin after I laid hold of the prisoner—the prisoner had just come out—it was an arm that came
from between the door and door-post, and it struck over the prisoner's left shoulder—I dare say I should know the arm again.

MARY BURCH . I am the prosecutor's wife—I remember my husband going up stairs on Friday, the 4th of February—shortly after that I heard a cry of "Thieves, murder"—I immediately went up stairs, followed by Ann Hayley, a young woman in our employment—she passed me on the stairs—I found my husband wrestling with the prisoner—Ann Hayley caught hold of the prisoner with myself—my husband, after giving him up to us, went into the bed-room—I was on the right-hand side of the prisoner—in struggling with him, I heard the sound of silver, or something broken—I could not discern which it was in the dark—it fell from his person—there was nobody else near enough for it to have fallen from—these five silver spoons are my husband's—we have had them four years—my husband had given me the key of the bed-room between ten and eleven o'clock in the day, at which time I put these spoons away between the bed and the mattrass—there is a dent in the bowl of one by which I know it—we lost a pair of salt-spoons, fifteen tea-spoons, and three watches—the spoons were in two separate drawers—two watches were in one drawer, and one in another—we lost seventeen spoons besides these, these five make up the twenty-two—the watches are worth 9l.—a seal, a watch-key, and silver buckle were lost, also a coin, a guinea, a crown-piece, several half
crowns, and some fourpenny-pieces.

Cross-examined. Q. You say the noise you heard in the struggle re
sembled something falling or breaking? A. Yes, it sounded something like silver—I did not see anything fall—I had hold of him on the right
hand side by the collar—Hayley had hold of the collar as well, as far as I know, my husband was looking for what he had lost—there were seve
ral people in the house—the prisoner was taken into custody—he did not get out of the house.

ANN HAYLEY . I was in the service of the prosecutor. About four o'clock on Friday afternoon, I heard my master call out from up-stairs—I immediately ran up and saw the prisoner come out of the bed-room—my master was in the bed-room at that time—I caught the prisoner by the collar as he was rushing down stairs—my mistress was with me—she did the same by the other side of his collar—the bed-room door is two Stairs down from a large landing which goes from the bed-room to the refreshment-room—you get to the bed-room before you get to the top of the landing—the prisoner was on the stairs when I got up—I saw him come out of the threshold of the bed-room door.

Q. Then you did not see him come out of the door? A. Yes, I did—we struggled down stairs with him—he was very resolute—further assist
ance came, and in the struggle I suppose the spoons fell—I did not see them drop—I heard them fell on the stairs—there was nobody near enough for them to have fallen from but the prisoner—the prisoner, my mistress and me, were the only persons on the stairs at the time—I am positive the spoons fell where we were struggling together—these are the spoons—I can identify this one that is dented.

Cross-examined. Q. Which stair were these spoons found on? A. I believe it was the fifth—I did not see them found—it was about four stairs from the bottom that I heard them fall—I did not go up stairs till I heard the cry of "Thieves, murder"—I saw the prisoner come out of the bed
room—I have no doubt of that—I did not see him shut the door after him

—I cannot say in what state the door was, for I was in such confusion—he was not on the top of the stairs when I went up—he was not a consi
derable distance from the door when I went up—he was running down stairs from the room—when I first saw him he was upon the threshold, half in and half out of the room—I am certain of that.

BENJAMIN PORTMAN . I live at Greenwich. On Friday afternoon the 4th of February, about four o'clock, I was in the Bell public-house—I heard the cry and ran up stairs, and about four stairs up I found the prisoner running down stairs, and cries of "Murder, thieves, thieves!"—he had got away from the women—I laid hold of him by the hair of his head—I am sure he is the man—he said, "Let me go," and made a blow at me—I heard a sound on the stairs, but saw nothing fall.

Cross-examined. Q. That was after he had escaped from Mrs. Burch and the servant? A. Yes—I did not hear the something fall very distinctly—it was when he was struggling with me that I heard it fall—I was not far from the women.
COURT. Q. What was it you heard? A. A sound on the stairs—what it was I cannot say—it was like a china bason falling—I did not look to see what it was.

GEORGE SULLIVAN . I am a ship's conductor, and live at Greenwich. I was at the Bell public-house on Friday, the 4th of February, between three and four o'clock in the afternoon, and heard cries of "Thieves" and "Murder"—I went up two or three stairs, and saw Portman there—he was before me, and had hold of the prisoner by the hair of his head—I took hold of him, and saw some spoons fall, some table-spoons, I suppose—I should consider they fell from the prisoner—there was nobody near enough from whom they could have fallen but the prisoner—I brought him down, and delivered him to the policeman, and I got a knock over the left eye into the bargain.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you lay hold of him after he had escaped from Portman? A. Portman had hold of him by the hair of his head, and I laid hold of him by the right hand—Portman went first—I saw something fall—I cannot say it was five spoons, but I saw some spoons fall, and sung out, "There are the spoons fallen"—on my oath, I did see some spoons fall—I cannot say at what part of the stairs I was—I did not see the spoons afterwards lying on the stairs.

Q. As you saw them fall, where did they fall from? A. Why, from the prisoner, I should suppose, he would not have made use of an observa
tion which he did, unless he was a guilty man—I saw the spoons fall—I do not say they fell from the prisoner—they fell on the stairs, higher than I was—I was below the prisoner—I saw them drop—I do not know ex
actly where about—I did not measure the distance—I navigate ships up and down the Thames, and have done so for ten years—I navigated one last Saturday—I live at Wood-wharf, Greenwich—I am not a water
man.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Do you know any thing of the prisoner? A. Nothing—I never had any quarrel with him.

WILLIAM ROMAIN (police-constable L 38.) I was at the Bell public-house on the Friday afternoon, about four o'clock, and the Prisoner was handed over into my custody—Mrs. Burch accused him of robbing her—she said he was in the bed-room—she said so in the passage—her words were, that he had robbed her, for she had found him in the bed-room—the
prisoner said he had made a mistake, he thought it was the refreshment room—I received charge of the spoons, and have produced them.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you search the prisoner? A. Yes, and found on him eleven shillings and five pence halfpenny, a knife, and a purse—I am positive Mrs. Burch said she had found him in the bed-room—she said be was in the bed-room.
Q. Then it is a mistake that she used the term "found him?" A. She said she had found him in the bed-room when she went up stairs with her husband.

CORNELIUS FOAY (police-constable H 98.) I was in the neighbourhood of the Bell public-house when the cry of "Murder" and "Thieves" took place—I ran to the house, and saw the prisoner on the stairs, and Sullivan having hold of him—they were struggling together, about three stairs from the bottom—I saw some spoons on the stairs like these, and I picked up a watch-key on the stairs at the same spot—the prisoner and Sullivan were nearly close to the stairs where I saw the spoons lie—nobody else was as close, except Mrs. Burch and Hayley—I found the things all thrown about in the bed-room.

WILLIAM RICHARD HARVEY . I was at this house on Friday, the 4th of February, and saw the prisoner coming down stairs, and Mrs. Burch and Hay
ley had hold of him—I heard something fall about half way down the stairs—the prisoner, Hayley, and Mrs. Burch, were about half way down the stairs at the time, at the same spot—there was no person near enough to have dropped the spoons where I saw them, but the prisoner, Mrs. Burch, and Hayley—there was no one on the stairs but myself, the prosecutrix, the prisoner, Hayley, Foay, Portman, and Sullivan—there were three or four other persons on the stairs besides Mrs. Burch and the prisoner.

Cross-examined. Q. Where did you find the spoons? A. About half way down the stairs, the whole five—there are about eighteen stairs—they were nearly at the bottom, rather better than half way down stairs—I did not count the stairs.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Was there any one near enough for the spoons to have fallen from, but the prisoner and the two women? A. No—they must have come from one of the three—I took the spoons up into the bed-room, and gave them to Mr. Burch.

EDWARD BURCH
re-examined. I did not give them to the constable—the officer went from the station for them—they are the same five spoons—they were given to me by Harvey—this watch-key is mine—it had been in the chest of drawers.

WILLIAM ROMAIN
re-examined. I was present during the whole of the examination before the Magistrate—the whole of it was taken in the pri
soner a presence—after it was over the prisoner was asked if he had any thing to say—he made no answer.
Cross-examined. Q. He was attended by a professional person? A. Yaes.

GUILTY of Stealing the Spoons. Aged 22.—
Transported for Seven Years.

1081.
JAMES STEVENS was indicted
for feloniously breaking and entering a building within the curtilage of the dwelling-house of
Ann Redpath, on 19th of February, at Plumstead, and stealing therein 1 bushel of onions, value 3s.; 1 basket, value 3d.; her goods; and 1 hat, value 1s., the goods of
Henry Nicholls .

HENRY NICHOLLS . I am gardener to Ann Redpath—we have an out-house at the bottom of the garden, which adjoins the house—the door of the house opens into the garden—there is a fence round the garden, part pales and part quickset, which separates it from the road—the dwelling house is inside the fence, and the out-house also—the out-house was locked with a padlock—on Sunday afternoon, the 20th of February, I found the prisoner at the station—he had a hamper containing seven ropes of onions belonging to my mistress, also a hat of my own, which I had locked up in the tool-house, close by the out-house, about six o'clock on Saturday night—I locked the tool-house up and left in it three ropes of onions and the hat—the hamper and four other ropes of onions were in an open shed—I went to the tool-house on Sunday morning, the 20th of February, after seven o'clock, and missed the property—I gave information to the police, and afterwards saw the property at the station—the tool-house was broker open, and the straw thrown out of the hamper—I can swear to the hat now produced, and know my own tying of the onions—I have no doubt they are my mistress's property—I cannot swear to the hamper, but it is similar to the one I lost—I do not know the prisoner.

CHARLES HIERONS . I am a policeman. I saw the prisoner at the corner of Connor-row, High-street, Woolwich, about eight o'clock on the Saturday evening, with a hamper on his shoulder—I asked what he had got there—he said, onions—I asked where he got them from—he said he bought them for 1s. of a man on the other side Plumstead, with a horse and cart, and he was going to Woolwich-market to sell them—there is a mar
ket there on Saturday night—I said I did not believe him, and he must go with me to the station—I found he had a hat over his own—he had two hats on—I asked where he got the two hats from, and nine apples which were in his pocket—he said he had the apples from the man he had the onions from, that the hat was a covering, not a hat, and that it was his own—I took him to the station, and fetched Nicholls—I produce the property.

HENRY NICHOLLS
re-examined. My mistress's house is on Shooters hill, in the parish of Plumstead—I know this hat to be mine—I have had it about a year and a half, and have worn it occasionally—there is a crack in the brim, which I did myself—I am certain it is mine—the onions are platted—I know my own platting, and can swear to it—we bad apples of this sort—I locked the tool-house up about ten minutes or a quarter to six o'clock.
Prisoner's Defence. I bought the onions at Plumstead for 1s., of a man with a horse and cart, in the road.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Six Months.

1082.
JOHN BROAD and
WILLIAM MOORE were indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of February, 127 yards of rope, value 10s.; and 2 1/2 lbs. of beef, value 1s.; the goods of
Edward Hopper Hebden and an
other, in a vessel on the navigable river Thames; to which

BROAD pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 54.

MOORE pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Confined four Months.

1083.
JOSEPH SMITH and
THOMAS RATTAW were indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of February, 41bs. of bread, value 8d., the goods of
Andrew Scotland ; to which

SMITH Pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 15.

RATTAW pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 15.
Confined Three Months.

1084.
ELIZABETH SMITH was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of February, 1 purse, value 4d.; 5 half-crowns, and 1 sixpence; the pro
perty of
James Williams, from his person.

JAMES WILLIAMS . I am a driver in the Royal Artillery. At a quarter before eleven o'clock on the evening of the 17th of February, I was in the tap-room of the King's Arm's public-house at Woolwich—the prisoner and five or six others were there—I pulled my purse out to pay for a pot of beer—I had then five halfcrowns and a sixpence, and enough halfpence to pay for the beer—in getting the halfpence out, the silver ran out into my hand, and the prisoner saw it—I put it into my purse, which I put into my pocket—I did not button the three lower buttons of my jacket—I then put my head on the table, and turned to speak to another young woman—the prisoner came to me—I found her hand in my pocket—I caught hold of her with the purse in her hand—she would not let it go—the was not drunk, nor was I—I had not been playing with her.

Prisoner. Q. When you missed your money, why did you permit the young woman beside you to leave your company; you had been sleeping on her shoulder; you said you knew where to find her on the morrow? A. She did not go away—when I got up to get the money from you, she sat still, and she is here now—the waiter got shoving me about and taking her prisoner's part—she went over to the other side of the room, where she had two or three more companions—the five half-crowns were taken out of the purse, but the sixpence is in it now—this is it in my purse.

SUSAN WATSON . I am single, and live at Woolwich. I was at the public-house and saw the prisoner take the purse out of the prosecutor's pocket—she took the money out and put it in her bosom, and wanted to give me the empty purse—I said, "Give the man his money"—the prose
cutor turned round and snatched the purse out of her hand.

Prisoner's Defence. The prosecutor and Susan Watson came in; they were there an hour and three quarters or two hours; they called for ale and then for gin, and moved from one seat to another; he laid his head on her shoulder and went to sleep, and the moment he roused up she left his company; I never saw the purse.

JAMES WILLIAMS
re-examined. I was not drinking gin, and ale with Watson—I had only one pot.

GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Six Months.

1085.
HENRY MOSES PAUL was indicted
for stealing, on the 18th of February, 60lbs. weight of chain, value 155.; 1 weight, value 5s.; 1 crow-bar, value 3s.; 2 iron bolts, value 1s.; and 1 iron wedge, value 1s.; the goods of
William Tuckwell.

WILLIAM TUCKWELL . I reside at Norway-wharf, Greenwich. I saw this chain weight, crow-bar, and iron bolts, safe on my wharf between five and six o'clock in the evening, on the 18th of February—I did not miss then till the policeman came, about a quarter before eleven the same evening—these now produced arc the articles.

PHILIP COLE . I am in the employ of Mr. Tuckwell. On the even
ing of the 18th of February I was ordered not to go to work but the prisoner was ordered to work; and then Mr. Tuckwell told me to tell him not to work—this chain and weight were in the place where they were lift between seven and eight o'clock that evening.
EMMA SHIRLEY . I keep a marine-store shop at Greenwich. the prisoner brought these things to me that night, between nine and ten o'clock, and I would not buy them.

Prisoner. I did not take the chain there, I never had it. Witness. This is the chain he brought—the policeman came immediately after—the chain was then lying where the prisoner put it—I am sure he brought it—he pitched it down in the shop—I knew the prisoner before—I cannot swear he brought the crow-bar, but he brought the weight, bolts, and the chain.

GEORGE BOOTH (police-sergeant R 2.) I received information—I went to Shirley's and asked what she had bought of a person, describing the prisoner—she said he had brought that chain, and left it there for the approval of her husband—Mr. Tuckwell came and identified it—I then found these other things in Shirley's house.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

1086.
JOHN GRAVES,
SAMUEL BINDING , and
JOHN MILES , were indicted for
stealing, on the 9th of February, 6lbs, weight of bread, value 1s., the goods of
Edward Winn; to which

GRAVES and BINDING pleaded
GUILTY .—
Confined Two Months,

CATHERINE BULLER . I am servant to Edward Winn, a baker, living in Trafalgar-road, Greenwich. At half-past one o'clock on the 9th of February, I was in the shop and saw Graves; he asked me to give him a piece of bread—I refused—he took a loaf from the counter and Binding took another—Miles came in with them, but he did not take anything—he went out with them.
MILES. I never was near the shop. Witness. I am certain he was.
JOHN PAGE (police-constable R 70.) I was on duty and saw the three prisoners eating the bread.

MILES—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Confined Two Months.

1087.
MICHAEL KEAN was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of February, 1 sovereign, 2 half-crowns, 3 shillings, 3 pence, and 2 half
pence, the monies of
Richard Pritchard, from his person.

RICHARD PRITCHARD . I am a seaman of the Abercrombie—I was at the Fishing Smack public-house at Deptford, on the 9th of February—the prisoner and another soldier came in—I then went to the King's Arms public-house—I sat between the two soldiers—the prisoner was on my right hand—in my pocket I had a sovereign, two half-crowns, some shil
lings, and some halfpence—I counted it at the fire, and sat down and called for a pot of beer—the soldiers drank it—I called for another—I put my hand in my pocket and missed my money—the prisoner got up and was going away—I caught hold of him and gave him to a policeman—while I was sitting down I had felt him rub against my jacket pocket—then was no other person by my right side but the prisoner—there was a penny
piece taken from him which I can swear to, it has a hole at the back of the bead.

Prisoner. Q. Had you not got a comrade? A. Not with me—the prisoner tore his pocket from his trowsers directly he got out of the door. and was going to throw the money away—the policeman caught it from his band—the prisoner said, "You need not be so fast, I was going to give it you."

WILLIAM LADD . I was in the public-house—I saw the prosecutor pay a fiddler—he then sat down by two soldiers—I saw the prisoner rub his arms against him—then the prosecutor went to take a drink of beer, and there was none—he put his hand into his pocket, and the money was gone—the prisoner got up to go away—the prosecutor seized him.
ELLEN MURRAY . I know the prosecutor—I was in the beer-shop. I know this penny-piece—I have often had it in my hand.

JOHN EDWARD GLASSCOCK (police-sergeant R 25.) At half-past eight o'clock that night, I was called, and took the prisoner—as we were coming out of the door, he put his hand to his watch-pocket, and tore out the money and pocket—he was in the act of throwing it away, and I caught it—here is 5s. 10d.—there is a half-crown among it—no sovereign was found—this penny-piece was one that was found.
Prisoner. Q. Did I desire you to search that woman? A. No.
ROBERT COUPE . I am sergeant of the 15th regiment. The prisoner has received no pay since the 9th of February—he has always borne a good character.
Prisoner. Q. What money had I in my knapsack? A. Five shillings.

Prisoner's Defence. I laid alongside the sailor, and when we got up to dance, we were all tipsy; this girl went and sat alongside of him; I or
dered her to be searched.
NOT GUILTY .

1088.
WALTER LANE was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Feb
ruary, 4 tame pigeons, price 10s., the property of
Thomas Slater.

THOMAS SLATER . I am a plumber, living in High-street, Deptford. I had some pigeons—one had a broken feather in the wing, and a spot under the beak—I saw them safe on Sunday, the 13th of February, in the afternoon, and missed them on Monday—these pigeons now produced are mine.

WILLIAM HENRY REEVES . I bought one of the pigeons on the 14th of February, between nine and ten o'clock, of the prisoner, for 7d.—he said he had bought them, but his father would not let him keep them.
HENRY WESTON . I bought two pigeons of the prisoner, for 9d., and another in exchange, on the 14th of February.

WILLIAM THOMAS ARTHUR (police-constable R 202.) I took the pri
soner—I told him I came about the pigeons—he acknowledged taking them and said he sold three, and one flew away.

GUILTY . Aged 13.—
Confined One Week Solitary, and
Whipped.

1089.
GEORGE OWEN was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of Ja
nuary, 2 blankets, value 17s.; 2 sheets, value 7s.; 1 counterpane, value 12s.; and 1 tablecloth, value 4s.; the goods of
Sarah Baldwin.
SARAH BALDWIN . I am a widow, living in Charles-street, Woolwich, In January, 1841, I let the-prisoner a lodging in my kitchen—he left me
on Saturday the 23rd of January—the following Monday I missed these things off the bed—they were let with the lodging.
JAMES ATKINSON . I am assistant to Mr. Moore, a pawnbroker in Eyre-street, Woolwich. I produce a blanket, sheet, and tablecloth pawned in January, 1841, to the best of my belief by the prisoner.

WILLIAM TWYMAN (police-constable R 127.) I took the prisoner on the 17th of February this year—I told him it was for robbing his lodging in Charles-street, Woolwich—he said he never lived at Woolwich—he said on his way to Woolwich, that he had pawned them, that he was in great distress, but that week he intended to send his landlady some money.
(Property produced and sworn to.)

GUILTY . Aged 46.—
Confined Four Months.

1090.
LOUISA MORTON was indicted
for stealing, on the 23rd of February, 3 work-boxes, value 7s. 6d., the goods of
Edwin Crowder.

EDWIN CROWDER . I am a perfumer, living in High-street, Woolwich. On Wednesday evening, the 23rd of February, about six o'clock, the pri
soner came to my shop—she made some excuse—I had had some work
boxes on my counter immediately before—I missed them an hour after
wards—no one else had been in the shop in the meantime—these pro
duced are mine.
EDMUND NORTH . I am a pawnbroker. I produce a box pawned by the prisoner on the 23rd of February, in the name of Louisa Morton, for Ann Read, Red Lion-street.

BARTHOLOMEW KING (police-constable R 176.) I took the prisoner—as we were going to the station, she said, "Another girl gave me the boxes, and said if I pawned them, she would give me one box"—she showed me where they were pawned.
Prisoner's Defence. A young woman gave them me to pledge.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Three Months.

1091.
HENRY BURKE was indicted
for stealing, on the 12th of Fe
bruary, 1 hamper, value 1s.; 25 bottles, value 6s.; and 4 1/2 gallons of wine, value 4l. 10s.; the goods of our
Lady the Queen, in a barge on the navigable river Thames.—2nd COUNT, stating them to be the goods of
Robert Laurence Frazer.

CHARLES MAY . I am steward of the Abercrombie Robertson, lying at Deptford—Mr. Selby is the owner—every thing on board is the property of the captain, Robert Laurence Frazer—it is a transport, and the Crowe provides the stores. On the night of the 12th of January I was called by the captain to go into the Trinity barge, which was lying alongside the ship, in consequence of the lighterman having called for assistance—when I got into the lighter I found Connolly and the prisoner—the third officer then went into the cabin of the lighter, and found a bottle of wine con
cealed—it was the same sort as had been placed in the barge Nelson, which was lying outside the Trinity barge—I had placed seven hampers of wine in that barge, which was to return them to the Victualling-oflice—it corresponded with the bottles placed in the hamper—there was one hamper missing, containing twenty-five bottles.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Do you know where the prisoner was working that day? A. On board the Trinity barge—I went on board the Trinity barge to see if I could find any more of the property—I found
no more—there were very few sailors on board our ship—I am not aware that the prisoner had any thing given him to drink that day—it might have been given him.

JOHN CONNOLLY . I am a waterman and lighterman. At half-past ten o'clock that night I saw the prisoner in the hold of the Nelson, which I bad locked down before dark—he was a stranger—I said, "Halloo, old boy, I have caught you at last; I suspect you have been robbing this barge that I have the care of"—I called for assistance—the steward and third mate came to my assistance—when I spoke to the prisoner he took something from his bosom, and threw overboard—it resembled glass—I heard the splash—I cautioned him not to throw them overboard, as they were left in my care.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he appear as if he had been drinking? A. He was intoxicated.
WILLIAM BELDAME (police-constable R 183.) I received the prisoner in custody, with this bottle and hamper, which were found in the barge where he was.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he appear tipsy? A. He appeared the worse for liquor—there was another person taken—I forget his name.
NOT GUILTY .

1092.
HANNAH PARKER was indicted
for stealing, on the 17th of February, 1 pair of scissors, value 2d.; 1 purse, value 1d.; and 1 shil
ling; the property of
Henry Cronk.

ANN CRONK . I am the wife of Henry Cronk, and live at Deptford. I had a pair of scissors, a purse, a duplicate in it, it shilling, and several other little articles, in a little basket hanging by the side of the fire—I saw them safe on Thursday, the 17th of February, about six o'clock in the evening, and missed them about nine next morning—I spoke to the police
man—the articles produced are them.

JOHN STRENGTH (police-constable R 96.) On the 18th of February the prosecutrix came and told me she had been robbed of a purse and several other things—I apprehended the prisoner at her mother's, and charged her with robbing Mr. Cronk—she said, if I would let her go she would tell me where the things were—I said I could not, she might do as she liked about telling me—she then went into the yard, and showed me a broken pane where she had put these things through—I went into the room, and found the articles in a bird-cage—here are the scissors, the puree and duplicate, and basket.

GUILTY . Aged 15.—
Confined Four Months.

1093.
HENRY BANKS and
HENRY DAY were indicted for
steal
ing, on the 4th of February, 1 purse, value 3d., the goods of
Eliza Bing, from her person.

ELIZA BING . I am single, and live servant at Plumstead. On the 4th of February I was at Woolwich, near Warren's-gate, about half-past two o'clock-there were several other persons there, but no one with me—I felt some one at my pocket, but I did not take notice what they were doing—I had only my purse and a duplicate in my pocket, for I had taken my money out a few minutes before, and had it in my glove in my hand—soon after I felt this I looked behind me, and saw the policeman with Day's hand in
the pocket-hole of my gown, and at the same time I saw my purse on the ground—Banks was standing close to Day, and the policeman had hold of him—this is my purse.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE. Q. The purse fell through your dress, did it not? A. I cannot say where it fell, or whether it fell under my dress—I saw it on the ground—I was examined at the Magistrate's—I did not say it fell from under my dress—what I said was taken down in writing, and read over to me.
Q. What you said was, "I saw the purse fall from under my dress." Is that true? A. Yes—I examined my pocket—it had not been cut, Banks. Q. Which side of Day was I standing? A. I cannot say.

JOHN WHITE (police-constable R 180.) On the 4th of February I was on duty about half-past two o'clock—I saw the prisoners arm in arm toge
ther near the Arsenal-gate—I saw Day put his hand into the prosecutrix's pocket, and as he was drawing out his hand I caught hold of him by the wrist—I said, "Where is your hand now? does that pocket belong to you?"—on drawing his hand out from the pocket, the purse fell on the ground, I believe—I saw it on the ground, but I did not see it fall—I told the prosecutrix to pick it up.
Banks. Q. Where was I? A. On the left side of Day, and his hand was in her pocket.

CHARLES HEARNS (police-constable R 228.) I was present. I saw Day's hand in the prosecutrix's pocket—I saw something fall between her clothes on the ground—I could not tell what it was, but it proved to he this purse.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you in plain clothes? A. Yes—I saw the purse fall at the time I saw Day's hand in her pocket.

EDWARD FARNELL . I am a barman—I was near the Arsenal-gate—I saw the policeman holding Day's hand in the pocket—I did not see Banks till afterwards, when he was in custody—I saw the purse lying on the ground—I did not see how it came there.

JURY to ELIZA KING. Q. How long before had you removed the money from your pocket? A. Not ten minutes—I had not moved at all—my gown was torn very much behind—I am sure I returned my puree into my pocket.
(Day received a good character.)

BANKS—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

DAY—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

p.hi:
Recommended to mercy—
Confined Three Months.

div1.p:
1094.
MARY ANN FINNINGHAM was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of February, 1 ring, value 10s.; the property of
George James Pul
len, her master.

ELIZABETH PULLEN . I am the wife of George James Pullen, and live in Park-street, Greenwich—the prisoner was in my service for four weeks—I had a ring safe in the beginning of January, in a small writing-desk in the room I generally sit in—I missed it on the 14th of January—I told the prisoner, and took up the carpets and searched the house thoroughly, but could not find it—this now produced is it.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What do you know it by? A. By a new stone which was put in, and a crack in the next stone—I have
had it seven years—I had not seen it since the 3rd of January—I always kept the writing-desk locked, and kept money and private papers in it.

MARY ANN BUSSY . I live near Mrs. Pullen—I know the prisoner—she said she had a ring to give away to a young gentleman as a keepsake—this is the ring she showed me—I saw it about a fortnight before she left her place.
Cross-examined. Q. How long did you see it? A. I only saw it once for about a minute—I never lived in Mrs. Pullen's service.
ALFRED BALDER being called on his recognizances, did not appear.
NOT GUILTY .

1095.
SEIK HAMOD was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of Febru
ary, 1 watch, value 2l. 8s.; 1 watch-guard, value 2s.; and 1 watch-key, value 1d.; the goods of
Haji Cossein.

HAJI COSSEIN (through an interpreter.) I had a watch and guard, and key, on board my vessel—it was safe in my box at four o'clock, I do not know what day—about five my box was broken open, and they were gone—this is the watch—(looking at one)—the prisoner was on board that day—I asked him if he took my watch—he wanted to strike me, and I let him go.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. How many Lascars were there on board? A. Three or four—I am serjeant on board the vessel, the prisoner was a sepoy—I was on board before him—he shipped at Bombay.
JAMES STEVENS . I am a pawnbroker—this watch was pledged by Mary McCarthy on the 22nd of February, for 1l., in the name of Mary McCarthy—she said it was for a Lascar.
MARY MCCARTHY . I cohabit with the prisoner—he gave me this watch to pledge-there was a chain besides, but a navigator broke that from my neck.

Cross-examined. Q. You are an unfortunate woman? A. Yes—I have seen seven or eight Lascars from the ship at different times—none of them besides the prisoner have slept with me—he slept with me last Tues
day week, and gave me four or five shillings-we have never quarrelled I swear—he can speak a little broken English.

CARDER BAUX (through an interpreter.) The prosecutor is my cousin—I know his chain which he wore round his neck—I saw it on McCarthy about eight o'clock one night—I do not know the day—I told a policeman of it.

1096.
GEORGE BARTILLO JAY was indicted
for stealing, on the 22nd of February, 1 oven, value 6s., the goods of
Robert Stedall, his master.

ROBERT STEDALL . I am an ironmonger, and live in Nelson-street, Greenwich. The prisoner was my shopman—in consequence of informa
tion, I gave instructions for some American ovens to be made, in presence of the prisoner—I put the tin on the counter for the man to select it—I had information that the prisoner was robbing me, and I understood he wished American oven made unknown to me, to take it away—I gave the for the ovens to be made—they were for stock—I wanted a lot of ovens to be made—I placed the tin on the counter for Blake, one of my

workmen, to make four ovens—he worked in a shop underneath the pre
mises—this was on the 21st of February—the man selected tin enough for four ovens, and took it down stairs—he selected what he chose—I was present, but I did not attend to the quantity he took—I left it entirely to him—on the following day I came to London, understanding that the oven would be taken away—I came away to get a shopman to supply the pri
soner's place, and to give the prisoner an opportunity of sending the oven away—I understood if I were absent the oven would disappear—the pri
soner did not reside in my house—he was there doing business—he was my principal shopman—I went away on the 22nd, and when I came back I made inquiry whether the oven had gone—I had before been to the police-office—I had seen the ovens in the progress of making when I left for London, but neither of them was finished—I found the oven had gone from my shop—I found there was no oven there—the other three were not finished—I found one had gone, and I understood the prisoner had sent it away—I sent for the policeman to search his house—I had pre
viously ordered the oven to be marked, and I discovered the marked oven in his house—this now produced is it.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You had only recently come to this business? A. About nine months—Mr. Suter was my predecessor—the prisoner had been working for Mr. Suter, and I took him with the business—Blake had been with Mr. Suter also—the prisoner had before this time had goods in my shop, and after he has had them, he bas entered them in the book, and I have been paid for them.

Q. Has he had goods without his telling you in the first instance, and entered them in the book? A. Yes, once, or twice, or thrice he might have had them—in the multitude of business I cannot recollect whether he has had them more than three times—he has had goods, and has paid for them, but not without telling me of it at the time.
COURT. Q. You said he had had goods that he has entered himself and not told you? A. Not that I am aware of, without first telling me of it.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Will you swear that? A. I believe he has never had goods without previously mentioning it—if I am obliged to swear, I would say he has, but I believe he has not—when I came home that day, I did not say any thing to the prisoner about the oven—I did not ask him if he had sent an American oven out that day—I swear I never did—when I came with the police officer, I asked him if he knew any thing of an American oven.

Q. Did you ask him if he had sent an American oven out that day, and was his answer to you, "Yes, I have," and did you say, "You have sent one to your own house?" A. He said, "Oh, yes, I have, and I was going to tell you about it"—that was the first word I said to him I did not say, "You have sent one to your own house"—in consequence of his answer, I said, "You must make some one else believe it"—I swear I did not say, "You have sent one to your own house"—he did not say, "Yes, I have, and I intended to tell you of it to-night when you returned Iron town"—he said what I have said before, and I immediately gave him in custody.

Q. Did he not say to you in answer to your question, "Yes, I have, and I intended to tell you of it to-night, on your return from town?" A. He said, "Yes, I have, and I was going to tell you about it"—I said "You
must make some one else believe that," and immediately gave him into custody—I have not got my books here.

JAMBS BLAKE . I am a tin-plate worker in the employ of Mr. Stedall. Last Monday week I had an order to make up four American ovens, two of No.2, and two of No. 3—the prisoner was present when I received those directions—I selected the stuff, and took it down to the workshop—in ten or fifteen minutes the prisoner followed me, and said, now that I had the chance, I might make that one for him—he had applied to me for me to make one for about four months—he had been applying to me to make him one on different occasions—I told him I would make him one this time—accordingly I took five in hand instead of four—I had an order for four from Mr. Stedall, and one from the prisoner, but I took the tin for the five before Mr. Stedall—I did not go twice for the tin, I took it all at once—Mr. Stedall saw me take the tin, but I do not know whether he ob
served that I took the tin for five.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you not do it on purpose? A. Yes, I was to do it—Mr. Stedall told me to make an oven for Mr. Jay if he wanted it.

COURT. Q. Then you told him the prisoner wanted an oven? A. No, Mr. Stedall had told me first—he said he had heard that Mr. Jay wanted, me to make him an oven unknown to him—he had heard that from another man, not me—the prisoner asked me before the other man to make one for him, and to make it unknown to Mr. Stedall, when Mr. Stedall would be out of the way—he asked me to make this oven for him, and I took the oven, and made it for him—Mr. Stedall went out somewhere the day after—I had the tin, and then the prisoner came down, and told me to push along with that oven, now the governor was out of the way—he said No. 2 would be quite large enough for him, and to push along with it—I went op stairs, and told him it was done, and he desired roe to give it to the boy who was in the habit of coming to take things to another shop—the boy came—I was in the shop—the prisoner desired him to go down stairs with Blake, and take an American oven—I went as far as the head of the stairs, but I did not give it to the boy—I thought I would go out for a few minutes—I went out for about seven minutes, and when I came back I saw the boy in the shop, and the oven by the side of him, in a basket—it was not covered—it was partly in and partly out—I did not put any thing over it.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Did not you and your master agree before he went out that you should mark the oven? A. I marked it—I do not know whether me and my master agreed—I know that I agreed to make the oven—I do not know that I and my master agreed that I should make an oven and mark it, and he should go out of the way—to the best of my knowledge I did not—I know nothing about my master's book—the prisoner may or may not have had goods in the shop, and entered them and paid for them, for what I know—I do not know the value of these ovens—I have heard they sell for 9s. 6d.—my master asked me did not the prisoner want an oven made—I said, "Yes, for four months back"—had promised him the last four months to make one—I was obliged to promise him—I cut out one two months ago while the prisoner stood by me, while my master was out—the prisoner and I were always at variance about this oven, because I would not make it.
Q. Did your wife send you to the watch-house? A. She came to it—she gave me in charge of a-policeman—that was not for brutal conduct to

her—it was because she was in a state of brutal intoxication—I went to the watch-house—I did not stay there more than two or three minutes—that was the night before last—I have not looked into my master's book's see if this oven is entered—I have nothing to do with the books.

Q. Upon your oath did you not strike your wife most brutally in pre
sence of this gentleman who is here? A. No—I will not swear that did not—will that gentleman swear she was not drunk?—when my master went out he did not agree with me about the time he should come back—I have had things from my master's shop—I expect to pay for them—I have not paid them out since—I do not know whether I pay the cost price or the price a customer would pay—I have got a bill of them from Mr. Stedall—I got the bill the first night I was going to pay money on them, which was last Saturday night week—I think it was on the Saturday he fore the prisoner was taken—I have paid money two Saturday nights—I have never had many things—I had some candlesticks, and a fender, and a kettle and saucepan, and various little things of that sort—I did not come so high us getting an oven.
COURT. Q. Did you take them, and tell your master after you took them? A. No, I asked him to let me have them, before I had them at all.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Where was the oven when the boy took it? A. Along side of him in the shop—I did not stay below that the boy nights go out with it—I went out so that I should have nothing to do with it, because the prisoner wanted me to give it to the boy—I knew it was gone—when I went down stairs to my bench to work I lifted up my bead and saw the boy go past with it—I waited at my bench, looking through the window—I expected to see the boy go by with the oven.

MR. CLARKSON to MR. STEDALL. Q. You made out a bill for Blake, was that after the prisoner was in custody or before? A. I believe it was previously—I will swear I made out the bill before the prisoner was is custody—I did not give Blake the bill—it is now on my desk—I did not charge him cost price.

GEORGE WEEKS . I am errand boy to Mr. Stedall. Between four and five o'clock on that day the prisoner said to me, "George, I have got as American oven down stairs; I bought the tin, and Blake is making is for me; I want you to take it to my house"—he said, "I have got some things going up that way, and I will get you to take it"—then he said, "Blake has done the oven, go down stairs and fetch it up; your basket is down there, put it in your basket and bring it up here"—he then said "Look sharp, mistress is out of the way," and then I took it.

Cross-examined. Q. Why were you to look sharp as mistress was out of the way, if the prisoner told you he bought the tin? A. He told me so, Sir—I brought the oven up into the shop—I do not know where Blake was—he was not in the bottom shop where I took the oven from—I have been living with my master ever since—my master and I have not had any conversation about this since I went before the Magistrate—he only told me to speak the truth—he told me so a good many times—he said so in this court, and in the shop—he said, "George, you know you will speak the truth"—I do not know how many times he has said so—he said so three or four times at the shop—Blake might have been by at the time he told me so—he has not told Blake to tell the truth in my hearing—the prisoner used to write in the books—he has not booked anything that he

has bought to my knowledge—I do not know who has got the books now—there is another shopman—my master spoke to me about this the same night that I took the oven home—not before I took it home, but after—Blake was in the bottom shop when my master first spoke to me—I did not know that it was all arranged—I was struck when my master asked me about it.
NOT GUILTY .

1097.
JOHN PHILLIPS was indicted
for stealing, on the 4th of Fe
bruary, 1 copper, value 19s., the goods of
Robert Stedall.

EDMUND EDWARDS . I am in the employ of Robert Stedall, an iron
monger, in Nelson-street, Greenwich. On the 4th of February he had this copper outside his door, and we missed it.
JOSEPH HOOKER (police-constable R 50.) I stopped the prisoner with this copper on the 4th of February, between six and seven o'clock in the evening.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Three Months.

1098.
JOHN DUDGEON and
JOHN POARCH were indicted for
breaking and entering a building within the curtilage of the dwelling-house of
John Tosswill and another, on the 20th of January, and stealing therein 3 bags, value 5s.; and 370lbs. weight of horse-hair, value 10l., their property: and
EDWARD PLATT
for feloniously receiving the tame, well knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

CHARLES BRIDGER . I am foreman in the service of John Tosswill and hit brother, who are in partnership as tanners and hair-merchants, in the Neckinger-road, in the Borough, in the parish of Bermondsey. On Thursday, the 20th of January, the prisoner Dudgeon came to our premises—I was then at work by the side of the horse-hair factory—he asked who the curlers of the horse-hair were—I did not satisfy him—he said he was in the line, and had come to seek employment—he walked round the place, and had an opportunity of seeing the premises—I did not give him employment—I secured the premises about nine o'clock on Friday night—the prosecutors' house does not join the shed—there are tan-pits, a warehouse, the room where the horse-hair is kept, and other outbuildings—the front of the house faces Neckinger-road—it is surrounded by a brick wall, with iron palisades—Horney-lane runs up from Neckinger-road, and the wall goes round that lane, and surrounds the warehouse with the iron fence, and from the iron fence it is all wall—there is a doorway, which is kept locked—it is one continued fence, inclosing the house and the shed within it—this plan (produced) is a correct description of it—at five in the evening I secured the warehouse where the horse-hair was, and took the key home with me as usual—I came to the premises at eight next morning, and found the house-hair-warehouse door broken open—the lock had been wrenched—I went in and found three bags of horse-hair gone—it had beep in bacon wrapper bags, which contained about 3 1/2 cwt. of foreign horse-hair, worth 11d. per lb.—it was un manufactured, and is never sold in that state—it

was worth about 18l.—it was safe when I left at night—I have since seen some horse-hair in the possession of Hornsby—I believe it to be masters'—there were some buffalo tails among our hair, and there are some among this produced.
Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. You do not know the value yourself? A. Not exactly.
Dudgeon. Q. Have not other people got buffalo tails among their hair? A. Yes, but it is rare to find it—it is not always so.
Dudgeon I went there to ask for work; it is usual to ask for the man before you speak to the master; he said they must not be seen.

RICHARD RHODES . I am a hair-sorter in the prosecutors' employ—I sorted a quantity of hard foreign hair a short time before Christmas, at my masters'—there was hair and dirt, and buffalo tails among it—it was these bagged up in five bags, called bacon wrappers, and put in a corner of the workshop, of which the foreman keeps the keys—it was in an un manu
factured state, not saleable for the purposes of trade—it was in a raw state (I saw the bag some time after Christmas) master would not sell it in the state it was in—it had two or three processes to go through—I have seen some hair in the possession of Hornsby, and really believe it is the hair taken from masters'—it is the same in every description—it is foreign un
manufactured hair, and has buffalo tails in it—there is about 3 1/2 cwt. of it, some black and some grey, and sorted, which was the case with what we lost—I think it is my masters' hair.

Cross-examined. Q. You do not think it is the same hair, do you? A. I really think it is—we sell hair when manufactured—it is not in the state in which it is imported—it is imported in bales, and I had sorted it—we have a considerable quantity in the warehouse—some bales bare buffalo tails, but sometimes you may sort a bale and not find a pound of them.

EDWARD ALLBURY . I am in the prosecutors' service. On the Satur
day morning I found the horse-hair shed broke open—I went round to the different marine-store shops in the neighbourhood to give information about it—about eleven o'clock I went to the premises of the prisoner Platt in the Mint in the Borough, and took a sample of the hair with me—I saw Platt, and showed him a sample of the hair—he looked at it—I asked him if he had bought anything of that sort that morning—he said "No"—I told him we had lost upwards of 3cwt. of hair from our manufactory that morning—he said he had not bought any—I asked him if anybody should call with any to stop them, and give them into custody—he said he would—I said if he went to Mr. Tosswell he would satisfy him for his trouble—he promised to do so—I said nothing about the bacon wrappers.

Cross-examined. Q. What quantity of hair did you take with you? A. A handful—the witness Collins was there when I went into the shop-l had no policeman with me—it might be a little earlier than eleven o'clock—I did not make a memorandum of what passed.
MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you a full recollection of what he said to you at the time? A. Yes.

JOHN TURFREY . I am a marine-store dealer, and live in Suffolk-street Borough. On Saturday morning, the 22nd of January, between nine and ten o'clock (I think) I am sure it was before ten, the prisoner platt came to my premises—he brought me a sample of horse-hair—I thought it was English horse-hair—he asked if I was a purchaser of hair—I asked him the price of it—he said 8d. a lb. was what he asked for it—I said I would give him

7 1/2 d., if it was equal to the sample—I do not recollect his saying how much there was—he agreed to take 7 1/2 d.—he wanted me to come down to his house to look at it—I said I could not, I was busy—he asked if I would send for it—I said I could not, I was busy, and should not be able to take it in for an hour or two—we agreed on the price, and he went away—he came back about eleven or half-past, with a donkey and cart and a little boy—there was three bags of hair in the cart—it was brought out of the cart and weighed—it weighed 3cwt. 2qrs. 21bs.—we tared the bags—I paid him 12l. 6s. 10 1/2 d.—I sold it the same day at 8 1/2 d. to Mr. Gallivan—Platt took the bags away with him—they were bacon wrappers—I have my book in which the transaction is entered.

Cross-examined. Q. You are a dealer in marine-stores? A. Yes, in the wholesale way—Platt is a marine-store dealer—I have been in business four or five years—I have known Platt five or six years—I never knew anything amiss of him—it might be half-past ten when he came—I consi
dered I paid a fair price—I sold it again the same day at 1d. a lb. profit—Platt came by himself in the first instance, and wished me to go to his house to see it—it might be half-past ten o'clock when he came.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Before you purchased this hair of Platt had any
body called at your shop to give you notice of its being stolen? A. No—I have bought goods of Platt, but never sold him anything—I have bought landrugs of him—I do not live so much as a quarter of a mile from him—I live in Suffolk-street—the Mint is nearly two miles, or a mile and a half from the prosecutors'.

JOHN COLLINS . I have been in Platt's service, and was so on Saturday morning, the 22nd of January—between half-past eight and nine that morning, I saw a sample of raw hair on the counter—it was before nine—Platt asked me if I could tell the value of it—I said I considered it was worth from 9d. to 9 1/2 d. a lb.—he went out with the sample, and was gone about ten minutes—after he returned, and, I think, before nine o'clock; Dudgeon came—master and him had some conversation—Dudgeon then went away, and came back about a quarter or half-past nine, with a truck containing three bags in bacon wrappers—they were full—Poarch was at the door with the truck and the bags—he took away the truck, and the bags were shot out on the pavement, and taken into the shop and weighed—I saw Dudgeon receive 7l. odd—he gave a bill and receipt for it in the name of Bailey—the last bag remained in the scale—it all remained in the shop until it was moved into a donkey cart, and left master's premises in the donkey cart, not later than ten o'clock at the very outside—master went with it—Dudgeon came again about quarter of an hour after the donkey cart had gone away—the bags were weighed, they weighed nearly 14lbs., and then they were taken away into the back parlour—the hair was not shot at mas
ter's, it went away in the bags in the donkey cart, but master returned with the empty bags, and then they were put in the bark parlour—they were weighed with the hair in the first instance—when Dudgeon came, there was a dispute between him and Platt about the value of the bags, and it was decided that they should be cut up—I and Platt cut them up—they were of less value after being cut up—they were afterwards taken away by platt and another who I do not know—I do not know where they went to—they were cut into five or six parts.

Cross-examined. Q. What became of the bags you do not know? A. No—I have been three or four days at work for Platt the last time, but have done work for him on and off for five or six years—I worked for him in

the shop—I never heard anything against his character or his dealings—the person who had the things called himself Bailey—Dudgeon signed the bill in the name of Bailey—I had never seen him before—I do not know whether he was a stranger to master—I stood in the shop about two yards distance—things might have passed which I did not see—I saw the money in Dudgeon's hands.

OWEN GALLIVAN . My father is a marine-store dealer in Collier's-rents, White-street, Borough—on Saturday the 22nd of January, I bought of Mr. Turfrey 3cwt. 2qrs. 5lbs. of horse hair—I did not know it was foreign hair when I purchased it—it was afterwards delivered to Hornsby the officer—it was in a raw state—we generally sell our hair to a hair mer
chant in Lant-street—I gave 8 1/2 d. a lb. for it—I should sell it at 10d.
Cross-examined. Q. You thought it was English? A. Yes—I bough it between two and three o'clock in the afternoon—it was in bags—it was delivered to Hornsby in the same state.

JOHN HORRABIN . I am in Turfrey's employ—I have examined two bags and a quantity of horse hair in the possession of the police, it is the same as I packed and delivered to Gallivan on Saturday, the 22nd of January—it is my own packing and delivering.
COURT. Q. Is it usual to buy the bag with the hair? A. No, we generally buy the hair and take the weight of the bag off, and return the bag—it was packed in master's bags,

GEORGE HORNSBY . I am an inspector of the N division of police. On Thursday the 27th of January, I went to the premises of Turfrey, and made inquiry of him about the horse hair—he gave me information and I went to Gallivan's premises, and there found the hair in question, which I have in my possession—I produce part of it, there was 3cwt. 2qrs. 5lbs. of it, bags and all—after I got it the prisoner Platt was brought to the station—I told him the charge—he said he had bought a little horse hair—I asked him what he called a little—he said there might be 2cwt. or 3cwt—Le did not know who he bought it of—he had given a fair price for it, and sent for a paper.

Cross-examined. Q. Did not he tell you he had purchased 3cwt.? A. No—he did not go with me to the station, I sent a man for him—directly I told him the charge he said he had bought some, and afterwards sent for the bill.

ROBERT TOSWILL . I am in partnership with my brother John, and have other partners—this is foreign hair—our premises are in the parish of Ber
mondsey—the hair was black and grey, and had buffalo tails in it-we bought about 3 1/2 cwt.—I had not seen the hair myself.

Dudgeon's Defence. I went over to Fresh Wharf, where I work, about seven o'clock; on returning from breakfast I met a man and asked him what he had there, and where he was going; he said he was going to the Jev Cohen, in the Dover-road, at the corner of Union-street; he said, "You know Cohen is shut up, being Saturday," and asked me if I knew where he could sell it; I said no; he asked me to show him a marine-store shop; he stopped at Platt's and asked me to sell it; Poarch was not with the man I met he said he wanted a porter; the man showed a sample first, and then re
quired me to go and sell it for him.

JOHN COLLINS
re-examined. There were several more standing in the road, but I only saw Dudgeon and Poarch with the truck.

(Richard Taylor, flock-maker, 11, Redcross-street, Borough; Benja
min

Holmes, hair-dresser, 13, Mint-street; Joshua Evans, eating-house keeper, 96, Blackman-street, Borough; James Williams, general dealer; Thomas Lloyd, woollen draper; James Westland, confectioner, 12, Mint-street; and Thomas Wagstaff, rag-merchant, 26, New-street; deposed to-Platt's good character.)

DUDGEON—
GUILTY . Aged 21.—
Transported for Ten Years.

PLATT—
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Seven Years.

POARCH—
NOT GUILTY .

1099.
JOHN THING was indicted
for stealing, on the 31st of August, at St. Mary, Newington, 12 spoons, value 5l. 15s.; 1 coat, value 3l.; 1 pair of trowsers, value 1l.; 1 pair of boots, value 15s.; and 1 hat, value 5s.; the goods of
Michael Meyers, in his dwelling-house: and 12 shillings, the monies of
Elizabeth Banbury.

MICHAEL MEYERS . I live at Kennington-common, in the parish of St. Mary, Newington, and keep the house.
