On the 26th or 27th of August last, I left my house and went to Aylesbury for three or four days, and on returning missed the articles named in the indictment, which I had left in charge of Banbury, my servant—I have found none of them except the hat, which the policeman brought to my house—it was one I had bought for my son Henry.

ELIZABETH BANBURY . I am the prosecutor's servant, and have been so fourteen months—the prisoner paid his addresses to me—I saw him in August last—I remember master's going into the country—I had the care of the plate while he was away, and kept it in the locker, which I locked—I saw it all safe on the morning of the 31st of August—the prisoner was backward and forward—I missed the spoons about five o'clock that after
noon—I also missed master's hat, coat, trowsers, and boots that evening, I did not see the prisoner with them on, but he left his own hat, coat, and boots in the house—I have never seen the plate again, nor the hat till the prisoner was taken, and the policeman brought it—it was Mr. Henry Meym's—I missed 12s. of my own.
Prisoner. Q. Are you certain that is your master's son's hat? A. Yes.

BARTHOLOMEW HERRING . I am a policeman. On the 12th of Feb
ruary, in consequence of information I received from the prosecutor, I traced the prisoner to St. George's-workhouse, and apprehended him—he denied the charge—I took this hat off his head, and asked where be got it—he said he bought it in Bishopsgate-street—Mr. Meyers identified it—I found nothing else on him.

MICHAEL MEYERS
re-examined. This is my son's hat, which was lost—I bought it for my son, who lives with me.

Prisoner's Defence. I was in the habit of visiting the female, and on Sunday evening another young man came there; several young men vi
sited her, and I left the house—soon after she left the house with this young man; the hat I bought in Bishopsgate-street; it was then a very good one; it had none of the appearances it has now.

MR. MEYERS. The hat was cracked here as it is now—the maker's name hag been torn out.
GUILTY of stealing, but not in the dwelling-house. Aged 21.—
Confined Six Months.

1100.
OSCAR DANTZAR was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Marten Fentross, on the 20th of February, and cutting and wounding him in and upon the left arm, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

MARTEN FENTROSS (through an interpreter.) I am a native of Dantzic in Prussia—I was cook on board the London packet, which was in the Com
mercial Dock—last Sunday week, at eight o'clock in the morning, I was standing near the steersman, near the stern—the prisoner stood next to me, and was continually aggravating me—he would not leave me alone threatening me one thing or other—he was the cabin-boy—I told him if he was not quiet I would give him a thrashing—he was continually annoying me, singing and hallooing in my face—when I said I would give him a thrashing, he said he would give me a beating again—he look a knife in his hand, with which he was going to pare potatoes for the crew—he took the knife and said if I was not quiet he would stick me, he would stab me—I told him I would tell the steersman of him—I was about going towards the steersman—I went and told the steersman to keep the boy quiet, and the prisoner came round me, laid hold of me, and stabbed me with the knife, on my left arm, inside the bend of the elbow, be said, at the moment, "The devil shall get you"—the Captain came up at the time.
Q. Did you strike or push him before he stabbed you? A. I took the broom from him previously, which he had in his hand, and pushed him in taking it from him.

CARL WILHELM KROHN . I am captain of the London packet. On Sunday week I heard a quarrelling on the deck of the vessel soon after eight o'clock—I went up on deck, and met the cook, who showed me his arm, and said, "I am stabbed by Oscar"—the prisoner was standings is the fore part of the vessel with a knife in his hand—I asked him how he could do so—he did not answer—I took the cook to the Hospital-ship after winding a towel round his arm—I took the knife out of the prisoner's hand, and gave it to the doctor at the Hospital-ship.

GEORGE BUSK . I am surgeon on board the Dreadnought Hospital-ship—the prosecutor was brought there with a wound about an inch and a half long, in front of his left arm, made by a sharp cutting instrument—the captain brought me the knife produced—it was exactly such a would as might be made by this instrument—it was rather more than an inch deep, and appeared to me likely to be attended with some risk at the time.

MARTEN FENTROSS
re-examined. I had done nothing to provoke him before he began to sing in my face—he kept aggravating me for a few minutes before he stabbed me.

GUILTY . Aged 16.—
Confined Six Months.

1101.
THOMAS CHRISTY TANDY and
WILLIAM SMITH were indicted for
feloniously breaking and entering the warehouse of
John Humphery, Esq., on the 15th of February, at St. Saviour's, Southwark, and stealing therein 1 firkin, value 1s.; 38lbs. weight of butter, value 2l.; 1 looking-glass and frame, value 10s.; 1 nest of drawers, value 5s.; 1 printed book, value 2s.; and 50lbs. weight of dried fish, value 5s.; his goods to which.

TANDY
pleaded GUILTY .* Aged 30.-
Transported for Ten Years.

GEORGE TOMKINS (police-constable M 166.) On the morning of the 15th of February I was on duty in Tooley-street, and about three o'clock hearing noise near the bridge, I went there and found the prisoner Smith running down Tooley-street as fast as he could—I met him in the face, and collared him—he was pursued by William Bowman—the water was running out of his clothes when I stopped him—I searched him directly, and found a "Johnson's Dictionary," with Mr. Alderman Humphery's name in it, a little iron chisel, and a large Spanish knife with a spring at the back—I said, "You are my prisoner"—he resisted very much, and said he had been chucked into the water by two big men out of a barge—I kept him till Bowman came up—I did net ask how he came by the book—I first saw him running under the dry arch from Mr. Humphery's wharf—I first saw him at the bottom of the steps, about two or three minutes' walk from Mr. Alderman Humphery's counting-house, as he must go up the steps, across the road and down the other steps—be was on the Tooley-street side of London-bridge.
Smith. I made no resistance.

EDWARD EDWARDS . I am a watchman at the Southwark Steam-wharf, which joins Mr. Alderman Humphery's wharf. In consequence of informa
tion from Frampton, I went in a boat to Hibernia wharf, and found the window of the counting-house of Mr. Alderman Humphery wide open—I went in with Frampton, and saw two men in the warehouse—it was the two prisoners—I am certain they are the men—one was banding some fish to the other—when I first saw them there was some kind of an arti
ficial light—as soon as we got into the counting-house it was put out—Frampton seized Tandy, and I took hold of Smiths-while I was trying to get him over some casks, we stumbled, and he got away—I saw him in the set of striking Frampton with a crow-bar, which I produce, which he had in his hand, in the warehouse—I forced it from his hand, and he escaped out of the counting-house window—I afterwards found he was secured by Bowman—I do not know whether he got away after that—I called to Bowman—he told me he had got him—that was on the steps of London-bridge,

Smith. This man says while he was getting over the casks I escaped, afterwards he says he rescued the bar out of ray hand; I was never in the place at all. Witness. I rescued it out of his hand in the warehouse after stumbling over the cask—I lost sight of him after he got out of the window.
Smith. Q. If there was no light how could you see me strike the Policeman A. We had a light of our own, a dark lantern belonging to Frampton.

WILLIAM FRAMPTON (police-constable M 52.) I was on duty in Mon
tague-close on the morning of the 15th of February, and gave information to Bowman—he and Edwards joined me—I got into a boat with Edwards we went at the counting-house window—there was a light in the warehouse—as soon as they heard us they put it out—I saw two men in the warehouse—I swear the prisoners are the two men—I am certain of them—Smith, was handing fish to Tandy—I seized Tandy, and Edwards Smith, but he got from him, and struck at me with this crow-bar—he went toward the counting-house window—I saw him in custody about an hour after—I counting-house window—I saw him in counting house with Tandy.

Smith. Q. Where were you when I struck at you? A. Standing at one end of the casks, and you were on the other—Edwards prevented the blow from striking me—I saw a desk in the counting-house broken open.

WILLIAM BOWMAN . I am watchman of Montague-close. On the 15th my attention was called to Hibernia wharf—something was said to me by Frampton—I listened, and heard somebody inside, and heard something distinctly break inside—I waited some time, but all the place in front was completely fast, so that nobody could enter there—I called Edwards—I watched the window of the counting-house, and saw the prisoner Smith get out of it—he ran along the quay of the warehouse, and jumped into the water, nearly breast high, then made his way towards the steps under the bridge—I followed him, and Edwards called out to know if I had got him—I said, "Yes"—he then turned round, and said, "You b—b—, if you offer to touch me I will kill you"—he immediately struck me on the neck—I pursued him, without losing sight of him, till he was stopped by Tomkins, in Tooley-street, nearly opposite Fenning's wharf—I saw the book, chisel and lucifer-box produced, taken from his pocket—there were some matches in the lucifer-box when the constable took it, I believe—I examined the counting-house, and observed the win
dow; it appeared, by the marks and indentations made in the shutters, that this large bar had done it, as it completely matched the marks—I examined the desk, and the marks on that, fitted this chisel found in Smith's pocket.

WILLIAM JAMES KENNEDY . I am a labourer at Hibernia wharf, in Mr. Alderman Humphery's service. On the night of the 14th I left the premises at seven o'clock—I shut them up, and fastened the counting-house window with a screw, which went from the bottom sash into the shutter, and fattened inside—the shutters were shut—here is the screw—it is broken—on break
ing that they could take the shutter down, and pull the top sash down—I saw the iron chest in the strong room—it had been removed from its pro
per place, where it had been the night before.

MR. ALDERMAN JOHN HUMPHERY . I am proprietor of the warehouse and premises in Montague-close, in the parish of St. Saviour, Southwark. I know I left it—it was locked up in the desk—I noticed it—I had the key of the desk in my pocket, and here is the lock, which was forced off—my name is in the book—the iron chest is where one of my clerks keep money—it was not broken open, but taken out of its place, in all appearance, to be put into a lighter, and there was money in it—we have lost a great deal of pro
perty before this—there was a firkin of butter, which one of the clerks had received the night before, taken into a lighter.

WILLIAM FRAMPTON
re-examined. I saw a lighter, about a quarter before three o'clock, and saw a man on the quay—the lighter laid alongside Mr. Humphery's wharf—it moved off afterwards—a man, in a short blue jacket and trowsers was in it—it was moved away while we were inside the ware house.
Smith. I was never seen about the wharf, and I was never near it; my work is always lower down.
MR. ALDERMAN HUMPHERY . I do not recollect his face exactly, but there are such a number of men, I do not recollect him personally.
Smith's Defence. I had been at work at the Commercial Dock,

enjoying myself with some friends, and it was rather late, and I was rather fresh; I was coming up in a boat; there were two men in the boat; just by London-bridge I found a man's hand in my pocket; I said, "Halloo, what are you after?" I had a "Ready Reckoner" in my pocket, which I kept to calculate my wages; the book was taken out of my pocket; I asked the man what he was doing; he said he had taken nothing from me; I said, "You have a book of mine;" he said, "Here is your book," and threw this one down on the seat of the boat; I took it up, supposing it was mine, and put it into my pocket, and, in the tussle, fell overboard; I swam ashore: there was a cry of "Stop thief;" I ran along to the steps; a man caught hold of me; I said, "Let go of me, I am not going to be drowned by a parcel of thieves;" I did not have the chisel or lucifer-box.

MR. ALDERMAN HUMPHERY
re-examined. The counting-house is inside the warehouse—the window which goes into the counting-house it part of the warehouse—the doors of the warehouse are much stronger than the shutters of the counting-house—you cannot get into the counting-house fairly without going into the warehouse.
(William Attenbury, a tailor;—Heath, butcher, Charles-street, St. George's;—Barber, hatter, Southwark-bridge-road; gave Tandy a good character.)

SMITH-
GUILTY . Aged 25.—
Transported for Fifteen Years.

1102.
HENRY LLOYD was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Fre
derick Beauclerk, on the 17th of February, putting him in fear and danger of his life, and taking from his person, and against his will, 11 sovereigns and 2 half-sovereigns, his property.

FREDERICK BEAUCLERK . I live at No. 3, Foley's-buildings, Black-heath. On the 17th of February, about eleven o'clock at night, I was proceeding from London to Blackheath—I stopped at the King's Arms public-house, in the Kent-road, to wait for an omnibus—I saw the prisoner standing outside the door of the King's Arms, and requested him to call in omnibus for me if any passed—he said he would, and I gave him a pint of porter—I had twelve sovereigns in my left-hand waistcoat-pocket at that time—I was perfectly sober—I had taken nothing whatever—no om
nibus came up, and I proceeded to walk—when I got about 300 yards from the house, the prisoner came behind me, and tripped me up—I fell back
wards on the ground—I felt his hand in my waistcoat-pocket—he immedi
ately took out the twelve sovereigns, and ran away—I saw his face by the gas lamp on the spot, while I was on the ground, and his hand in my pocket—I am quite certain of him, and I am quite certain that the person who threw me down and took my money, was the person to whom I had given the pint of beer—he ran away towards town—I got up, and proceeded towards my residence—I did not follow him—I looked back, and he was gone out of sight—I followed back a few yards, but did not see any thing of him, and have not the least idea what became of him—I gave a full description of his person at several station-houses—I saw him again next day, and he perfectly agreed with the person—he only put his hand into my waistcoat-pocket, where my money was—he had not seen my money at the inn—he might have heard it jink—I might have been playing with it in my hand in my pocket.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. I believe you claim to be re
lated

to a noble family in this country? A. Yes, I am—I was quite sober on this night—I am of sober habits certainly—I have been shot out at my lodgings at Blackheath, and could not get in—I believe I have been once at the station when drunk—I think I have been twice in the last twelve months—I can swear I have not been half a dozen times—I do not see what that has to do with my being robbed—I am not quite sure I have been half a dozen times at the station within twelve months for being drunk—lean swear positively the prisoner is the man.

Q. Have you never said, "If he is not the man, he is very like him?" A. A person said to me to-day, there was another person like him about the neighbourhood—I never said, "If he is not the man he is very like him"—he certainly is the man—the prisoner did not produce witness before the Justice to prove where he was that night, that I know of—he said he could produce witnesses that he was half a mile from the place—a witness was called, and he stated so—the Magistrate said to me, "You have sworn positively to him, I shall admit him to bail"—he said he should re
quire 200l. bail—I said J knew the prisoner by his eyes, either grey or blue—they were certainly not dark eyes—I am not aware that my habits have been considered a little eccentric—I was waiting at the King's Arms a quarter or half-an-hour—I had come from Charing-cross—it must bare been about nine o'clock when I was at Charing-cross—I walked from there—the King's Arms is opposite the Bricklayer's Arms—it had not gone eleven when I was there—it was somewhere near eleven o'clock—I had been to a friend's named Bow, a carver and gilder, in the neighbourhood of Bedford-street, Covent-garden—I was waiting there to see him, but did not see him—I waited about two hours—I had no refreshment at his house, or any other house—J had left home in the morning—I cannot swear what time—it was before dinner—I did not dine anywhere—I went to town to see Mr. Bow—I got to his house about one o'clock—I went nowhere particular afterwards—I walked about, and called there again to see him—he had not got home—I wanted to see him on business—I walked about for six boon—I do not recollect that I went into a public-house—I will not swear I did not—I will swear I did not go into more than two—one was the King's Arms, and the other a house in the Strand—I do not know the name of, it—I drank rum-and-water there—that was about the middle of the day—I swear I only went to one public-house before I got to the King's Arms at eleven o'clock at night, and I only had some rum-and-water—I did not frequent the King's Arms—I might have been there before, but was not in the habit of frequenting the house—I did not, to my recollection, go the day after the robbery to any public-house besides the King's Arms to inquire if I had been there the day before—I might have called at the Grew Man, Kent-road, but do not recollect calling at the Swan—I did not call there—I called at the Green Man to see if I could see the prisoner inside, if I could recognise him in the house—I had never seen the man who robbed me, before that night—I do not think I went to the Green Man to ask if I had been there the night before—I went inside to see if I could recognise the prisoner there—I did not go into all the public-houses on the right and left down the Kent-road—I went to the Green Man, thinking it possible I might see him there, as it was near the spot—I should say it is not quite half a mile from the spot—I do not know the Swan—I called at no other public-house but the Green Man—I paid for a pint of beer for the man who robbed me, and took it outside the King's Arms to him—I

did not state before the Magistrate that I took some coppers out of my waistcoat-pocket, and gave them to the prisoner to go in and buy himself me beer—I think I paid for the porter myself at the bar—I do not re
collect stating that I gave him the money, and sent him in for the beer—the Magistrate called in the landlord, and he said he never saw the pri
soner, but it was me that came for the beer, and then I believe the clerk altered my deposition—the policeman went with me to the Green Man, but not to any other public-house—I do not recollect the policeman mak
ing any observation about my description of the person—my description of the man was such he could not hesitate about—it corresponded so ex
actly—I do not recollect his saying that from the description I had given of the person he should never have taken the prisoner—the description I give was quite sufficient—any one who had got his senses must have recognised him—I met one policeman on my road home after I was robbed—I only recollect meeting one—I told him of the robbery, and gave him a description—he is not here—I did not take his number—I went on my way.

DONALD FRASER . I am a policeman. On the 18th of February, be
tween four and five o'clock in the afternoon, I went with the prosecutor into the King's Arms public-house, and inquired of the landlord if he had seen the prosecutor there the night before—he said, "Yes"—I asked if he had seen any person in company with the prosecutor—he said, no; he recollected his speaking to somebody outside—we then went to the Green Man and to the Swan public-houses, but not inside—we then went to the Bricklayer's Arms public-house—I told the prosecutor to go in and see if he could see the person who robbed him—he came out, pointed to the prisoner, who stood at a little distance, and said, "I think that is the man that robbed me"—I told him he must be very certain he was the right person before I could take him, and told him to go and look at him—he went to him, and spoke to him—I did not hear what he said—I went near him—he looked round, and then he said he was the man that robbed him—I asked him again if he was certain he was the person who robbed him—he said, "Yes, I am certain that is the one that robbed me; I know his voice"—I then took the prisoner to the landlord of the King's Arms to see if he recollected seeing him in the prosecutor's com
pany the night before—the landlord said no, he did not see him—the pro
secutor had previously come to our station that same day, and given a description of the person who robbed him—he described him as a person about twenty years of age, rather short, and stout—he was asked whether he was pock-marked or not—he said at first he was not sure, but after that he said he was pock-marked, and that he was dressed in a black coat—I believe he said he was of a light complexion, but I cannot be sure—I do not believe he said anything about his eyes—I searched the prisoner, and found 4s. 3d. on him.

Cross-examined. Q. Should you have taken this man up from the de
scription Mr. Beauclerk gave? A. No, and so I stated—he said some
thing about blue eyes—I never saw the prosecutor before this transaction—I belong to the Walworth station—the prosecutor came to our station between four and five o'clock in the afternoon, the second day after the robbery—he was dressed as he is now.
MR. BEAUCLERK re-examined. I went to the Blackheath station first,

and they told me to go to the Walworth station—I gave a true descrip
tion of the prisoner, and it fully corresponds.
(Witnesses for the Defence.)

WILLIAM JOHN LLOYD . I am the prisoner's brother—he lives with his mother, at No. 6, William-place, Prospect-row, Walworth-road—he has been latety engaged in transacting business for Mr. Staples, an up
holsterer at Chatham, making purchases for him, and sending them down by van—I remember Thursday the 17th of February, the day before my brother was apprehended—I got to my mother's house that night about half-past nine or a quarter to ten—my mother was dangerously ill at that time—my brother was then gone in search of a medical man, and returned in five minutes after I arrived—Mr. Prior, the doctor came in less than five minutes after my brother returned—my brother let him in—I was in the passage—my wife was with me—I live at No. 2, North-street, East-street, Walworth—I had occasion to go home, and told my wife so—I looked at my watch then, and it was half-past ten—I had left my house on the latch, and no person in it—I went out of the door about a quarter to eleven—at that time I believe my watch to have been ten minutes too fast, but I did not know that till Saturday—when I went out of the house it wanted less than a quarter by my watch—I then walked up and down the place for about ten minutes with my brother—he and I came out of the house together, and we had some conversation while I was waiting for my wife—I think it must have been eleven o'clock when I parted with my brother—within five minutes, either way—I parted with him at the corner of William's-place, which is about three-quarters of a mile from the King's Arms—my brother wore very light drab trowsers that day—I never knew any charge made against him in my life—when he left me he turned to the right—there is a beer-shop at the corner, and he turned, I believe, to go there—that is away from the King's Arms—I be
lieve he turned into the house—he said he had some instructions from Chatham—we walked about 100 feet from my mother's house.

ANN HARBERD . On Thursday, the 17th of February, I was acting as nurse to the prisoner's mother, who had been very poorly for a few days—I remember that Thursday—the prisoner was at home all day, till he went for the doctor in the evening, which was, as near as I can guess, between nine and ten o'clock—he returned in about a quarter-of-an-hour, and had been unable to find the one he went for—he then went for another, and was gone about ten minutes—he then returned, and did not leave the house any more till he went away with his brother—his mother was seri
ously ill—we were in very great fear of her till the doctor came—the pri
soner was very much hurt to see her so—he appeared distressed, and even cried.

COURT. Q. What time did the doctor come in? A. About ten o'clock—it was Mr. Prior—he staid about twenty minutes—when the prisoner went with his brother, he had to go for some orders a few yards off, which his master sent for him at eleven o'clock that night—he came in again before twelve, and slept at home that night.

JOHN BURKIT . I am in the service of Mr. Staples, a broker and up
holsterer, at Chatham—the prisoner has been in the habit of purchasing things for Mr. Staples, who sends his van to London by me to receive them, and has done so since August last—I was in town with the van on

Thursday, the 17th of February—I cannot tell the name of the street, my stable is in, but it is within twenty-three paces of the prisoner's house, for I paced it this morning on purpose to be sure—the prisoner kept the key of that stable for me and my master—I came to town that evening, and it was about half-past nine when I got to the stable—I called at the prisoner's mother's house, where he lives, and saw him—he told me his mother was ill—he gave me the key of the stable—I told him I had an order for him, and money with it—I had been constantly in the habit of coming up to him with money and orders, according to my master's direc
tions—he said he would go and get it the first thing in the morning, it being go late that night, and he had been for the doctor—I afterwards ap
pointed to meet him that night at the beer-shop, where I always have my meals, at the top of the lane—I went to the stable, groomed my horse, and then went to the beer-shop to have my supper—the prisoner came to me there at or near upon eleven—I cannot say for a few minutes either way—he remained with me at the beer-shop till within a quarter or ten minutes of twelve—I gave him the money and the order there, and parted from him against my stable-gate, within twenty-three paces of his own house—he went straight to his own house from me.
NOT GUILTY .

1103.
JOHN THOMAS was indicted
for feloniously assaulting
Daniel Bradley, on the 28th of February, with a felonious intent to rob him.

DANIEL BRADLEY . I live at No. 4, Wild's-buildings, Borough, in the parish of St. Saviour, Southwark, and work at a hop warehouse. On the night of the 27th of February, I was returning home along Holland-street; a female addressed me and asked where I was going, I said I was going home; she said would I go home with her—I said not, and went on—I turned down the street, and she came down on the same side of the way, as far as a house near which I was attacked; she wanted me to go in there, I refused—she used some words—I said I did not care for her as tong as I behaved myself well—I went about five yards from the place, and three men attacked me, a few yards from the house; one of them came up the street, and struck me a blow in the face—I cannot say where they came from—they said nothing to me—one of them struck me in the face, and the other two attacked me severely—they struggled with me a few moments, till a woman and her husband was passing, and the husband interfered—I knocked the prisoner down, and kept him till the policeman came up—the men were stranger to me—I was sober—the first thing they did was to strike me; and the other two struck me about the body—they said nothing—no attempt was made to take anything from me—they could not overhear any conversation between me and the female.

Prisoner. I was coming from my aunt's, and went down Moor-street—I had drunk a little, and ran against him; he struck me in the eye—that made a disturbance between us; two men came and interfered because he kicked me in the gutter. Witness. I did not touch him till I was attacked—the party who came up struck me in the face; then the prisoner struck me—I got him down two or three times—he is not the man who struck me first—they said nothing about my money or anything.
Prisoner. There was no attempt to rob; I lout three half-crowns
myself in the row; he hit me in the eye and rolled me in the gutter. Witness. It is not true.

MARY CRANFIELD . I am the wife of Richard Cranfield, of Isabella
row, Lambeth—my husband is a smith. On the night of the 27th of February, about twelve o'clock, I was leaving a house in Ewer-street; I stood at the door and saw a female talking to the prosecutor in a very improper manner, because he would not go up the street with her—the prosecutor walked on towards the house, and the female stopped him against the door and began talking to him again—I heard her say some
thing very improper—he said no, he would be d—d if he would—he was going from her—she said something about she would make somebody—I saw three young men standing at the corner of a court or gateway, and heard one of them say "She cannot get him in;" and when the prose
cutor was leaving her, the three ran up the street—I saw one of them strike him—I called to my husband, "Come, here is a man will be killed"—we went up the street; the prosecutor and the prisoner were fighting as it were, and the other two struck him a blow—my husband tried to get the prisoner away—I hallooed "Police;" and one of them came up to me and said, "If you do not hold your tongue calling Police, I will kill you"—I ran to the top of the street, and called "Police" again; the police came down—I said several times that the prosecutor's hat was taken into the house, she was endeavouring to get him in too, calling watch; and it was at last thrown out of the door or window—he kept hallooing out, "My watch, my watch, mind my watch"—the female and the other two men ran away when the policeman ran down the street.
Prisoner. She did not come to the station that night. Witness. I was there, but was so ill; the policeman said what I had to say I could say to-morrow.
Q. Did not he have me in the gutter? A. You both fell—I never saw either of you before—it happened near Ewer-street, which is in Union street.

ROBERT BRANFORD (police-constable M 101.) On the 27th of Feb
ruary, between twelve and one o'clock, I heard the cry of "Police" in Ewer-street; I went up, and saw the prisoner holding the prosecutor's coat, and both struggling together—the prisoner was beating the prosecutor with his fist—there was several others about him—as soon as I made my appear
ance they ran away—I knew the men who were about the prisoner by sight.

Prisoner. I was down in the gutter when he came up, and was kicked in my rib. Witness. They were both standing up when I collared the prisoner—he resisted very much; if he fell it was before I came up.

GUILTY .* Aged 20.—
Confined Three Years.

1104.
ROBERT CRAWLEY,
EDMUND BROWN,
THOMAS HARRIS , and
JOHN DAVIS were indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Alfred Staines Pigeon, at St. George the Martyr, Southwark, about the hour of one in the night of the 13th of February, with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 2 shawls, value 2l.; 1 brooch, value 10s.; 1 thimble, value 2s.; 1 purse, value 1s. 6d.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 2s.; 1 piece of damask, value 5s.; 1 table-cover, value 5s.; 2 gowns, value 30s.; 1 pair of ear-rings, value 5s.; 1 penknife, value 6d.; 1 handkerchief, value 2s.; 1 sovereign, and 1 half-sovereign, the goods of
Sarah Matilda Kendall: 1 gown, value 1l. 1s.; 1 boa, value 1l.; 1 shawl, value 10s.; 2 pairs of stockings, value 2s.; 2 brooches, value 6s.; 2 pairs of ear-rings, value 10s.; 1 purse, value 1s. 6d.; 1 umbrella, value 5s.; 1 scarf, value 10s.; 9 yards of cotton, value 5s.; 1 night-gown, value 3s.; 2 thimbles, value 4s.; 1 penknife, value 2s. 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Elizabeth Ann Hudson: 1 pistol, value 4s., the goods of
Frederick Crafts: and 4 forks, value 3l.; 11 spoons, value 3l. 10s.; 1 toast
rack, value 10s.; 3 half-pounds weight of tea, value 15s.; 1 tea-pot, value 10s.; and 2 table-cloths, value 1l. 5s.; the goods of the said Alfred Staines Pigeon; and that Harris had been before convicted of felony: and
RHODA WELLS
, for feloniously receiving 1 handkerchief, and 1 pair of ear-rings, part of the said goods, knowing them to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.: and
EMMA ELIZABETH DUDLEY , for feloniously re
ceiving 1 purse, part of the said goods, knowing it to have been stolen; against the Statute, &c.

SARAH MATILDA KENDALL . I live as cook in the service of Mr. Alfred Staines Pigeon, in High-street, Borough, in the parish of St. George the Martyr, Southwark. On the night of the 12th of February I went to bed between eleven and twelve o'clock—I saw that the fastenings of the house were quite secure at that time—I got up next morning at eight, or a few minutes past—I found the house had been entered by the knife-room window, a square of glass was cut out, through which the window could be un
fastened—the window was open—the knife-room communicates with the kitchen—I missed from the kitchen some table-forks, fifteen dessert-spoons, some dessert-forks, and tea-spoons, all silver, a tea-pot, a toast-rack, and a wax-candle from the pantry-drawer, a handkerchief from the kitchen-dresser, and some ear-ring tops from the table-drawer in the kitchen—they were ray own—I also missed of my own, two shawls, one silk dress, a gold brooch, a pair of jet ear-rings, a silver thimble, a sovereign, and a half-sovereign in gold, some silver, a bead-purse, a penknife, with a tor
toise-shell handle, and two pair of black cotton stockings—the value of the things I lost was 10l., and about 10l. worth of property belonging to my master—there was a pistol missed from the kitchen—the back of my master's premises adjoin the backs of the houses in Mint-street, Borough—my master occupies the whole house—no one was up before me in the morning, and I came down about eight.

Q. Was there anything to show that the parties who rummaged the premises had occasion for a light? A. Yes, a wax candle had been lighted, I because there were drops of wax on the kitchen-table, as if it had been burning—a piece of cotton-candle had also been lighted, and was left in the chimney—the wax-candle had been in the pantry-drawer over night—I had seen it there—it was a whole candle then—none of it was left—It was taken away altogether.

ELIZABETH ANN HUDSON . I am house-maid to Mr. Pigeon. I came down stairs with Kendall about eight o'clock on the morning of the 13th of February—I found the knife-room window open, and some glass cut—immediately outside the window is a leaden gutter, which divides the roof of the distillery from the window—a person could get into the window very easily from the roof of the distillery—the back premises of my master's house adjoin the backs of the houses in Mint-street—I missed from the

kitchen one dress, a printed cotton dress unmade, a squirrel boa, a scarf, shawl, a square shawl, a bead-purse, a night-gown, and two pairs of black stockings—my things were worth about 6l.—each of us lost a bead purse from the pantry-drawer I missed a wax-candle, which I had seen safe the night before, after six o'clock, not later, to take notice of it—I went to bed between eleven and twelve—the candle was larger than wax candles usually are—I have since seen a piece of wax-candle produced by Twit
chett, the policeman, and as far as I can judge, it appears to be the same.

EZRA TWITCHETT (police-constable B 114.) I apprehended Crawley and Brown on the 17th of February, about three o'clock in the morning, in the cellar of Mr. Piercey's public-house, St. George's-place, Knights-bridge—they had a piece of candle with them, which was alight when I first saw them, and Brown was carrying it—they blew it out previous to my taking them, and concealed themselves behind a gin-vat in the cellar—I searched near the vat, and found this crow-bar, n box of cigars, and this piece of wax-candle by the side of the gin-vat—I afterwards showed that pieced candle tp Mr. Pigeon's house-maid—a little while before I apprehended Crawley and Brown, I saw Harris and Davis on the opposite side of the way to Mr. Piercey's, and after that, two left the other two and went on the opposite side of the way—that was about one o'clock—I remained there watching—they separated about a quarter of an hour before they entered the house, which was about a quarter before two—I took Harris and Davis into custody about eleven that same morning, in the Broadway, Westminster, which is about a mile from Knightsbridge.
Crawley. He says he found us behind the vat; I was not behind a vat, it was a barrel; there was no vat in the cellar. Witness. He was behind a vat or barrel.

Harris. Q. How do you know Davis and I are the same two you saw? A. I am quite positive of you—I saw you all four together, and after that I saw you and Davis separately in St. George's-place, and passed you several times.

HENRY BAREFOOT . I am an inspector of the B division of police. On the morning of the 17th of February, the four male prisoners were locked up in the cell at Queen-square office, and the two female prisoners brought refreshments to the four male prisoners—I desired two constables to take the two women to the station, and I followed in the rear—they gave their address as Nos. 10 and 11, New-square, Orchard-street, Westminster—Wells said No. 10—they accosted a girl on their way to the station, whose name I do not know, gave her the keys to open the apartments, and desired her to do something in the apartments—I took that girl into custody also—Wells said she was sister to Brown, and Dudley said Crawley was her brother-in-law—I went with the girl to whom the female prisoners gave the keys, to No. 11, New-square, to the first-floor, front-room—she un
locked the door with the key which had been given her by Well—I searched that room, and found there a pistol secreted in the mattress—I have since shown the pistol to the prosecutor's servants—I found nothing else there—I went with the same girl to No. 10—she unlocked the door of the first-floor front-room there with the key which Dudley had given her—I found this bead purse in a drawer in that room—I took this silk handkerchief from Wells's neck at the station—at that time I had not heard any thing of Mr. Pigeon's robbery, and I let the female prisoners go—after hearing of this robbery, I caused them to be taken again, on the 22nd—I went to their lodging on the 21st, and they were not there—I

took from Wells's ears, at the station, these jet ear-rings—I have shown them to Kendall, and she claims them—Wells said she had had them fifteen months in her possession—both the female prisoners admitted lodging at No.7, Mint-street, Borough, on the night of the 21st—I have examined the state of the houses in Mint-street, with reference to Mr. Pigeon's pre
mises—from what I have observed, a person could go from the houses in Mint-street on to the roof of the distillery, and so in at the window of the knife-room—I did so myself, and saw there were marks on the tiles—I have no doubt a person could open the window of the knife-room by means of the broken pane of glass.

Davis. Q. You say these females brought us refreshment at Queen-square, did you see them bring any to me? A. I saw them bring it to you all four—you were all in custody at the time—the first I saw of you and Harris was in the tap-room of a public-house, and from the description given by the constable at Knightsbridge, I sent him with two or three other officers to see if you were the parties—they did not find you there, but close by, in the neighbourhood—I am sure you were in custody at the time the refreshment was brought—it was taken to the man's-cell—there is but one man's-cell, and all the four male prisoners were in it—I did not sec the refreshment distributed, but you were all talking together before you were locked up—when Harris and you were taken into custody you were taken into the officers' waiting-room, while I took your names and addresses, and you had to pass Crawley and Brown.

Davis. I had no refreshment; my friends did not know I was taken up; Harris and I sat by the fire, and we saw neither of the other prisoners till we were brought in before the Magistrate; Witness. That is not correct—they had to pass by the other prisoners who were waiting to go before the Magistrate—they had opportunities of speaking before, and I have no doubt they did speak together—I heard them do so—I could not distinctly hear what they said, but I heard them speak as they passed—they recognised each other—in going from the street to the office, they had to pass the prisoners Crawley and Brown, and after taking down their names and addresses in the officers' waiting-room, they had to pass them again—there is a room kept entirely for prisoners to wait in before they go before the Magistrate—Crawley and Brown were waiting there, and Harris and Davis when taken, had to pass them to come into the officers' waiting-room—then on the charge being called in against Crawley and Brown, Davis and Harris had to puss them again—they were nearly together in passing—it was quite momentarily—I am quite positive they spoke to each other.

Dudley. I deny taking any food to any body but my brother-in-law Crawley. Witness. I conclude it was for the four, from the abundant quan
tity—Wells represented Brown to be her brother.

WILLIAM UPCHURCH (police-constable B 25.) I assisted in appre-hending Davis and Harris about eleven o'clock on the morning of the 17th of February, in the Broadway, Westminster—I found this penknife on Harris, which is claimed by Hudson—on the morning of the previous day, the 16th, I saw all the four male prisoners in company together in Orchard-street, Westminster, about half-past eleven—they were coming out of New
way-square, or New-square, Orchard-street, together, one after the other—all the six prisoners lived at Nos. 10 and 11, New-square—the four male prisoners were within a very few yards cf their lodging when I saw them.
Davis. I deny it.

JOHN VASEY . I live at No. 1, New-square, Orchard-street, Westmin
ster, which is directly opposite Nos. 10 and 11. The prisoners Crawley, Harris, Davis, and Dudley lodged at No. 10—I have seen them in No, 10 several times—I have seen Brown in company with the other three male prisoners—Brown lived at No. 11, in the first-floor, front-room, and Wells with him—I could see them quite plainly from my house—I have seen all the four male prisoners go in and out of both those houses several different times—the last time I saw them go into those houses, was in the early part of the week previous to their apprehension—I saw all of them—it was about the 13th—on the Monday morning, between ten and eleven o'clock, I saw Crawley, Harris, and Davis go down the street together from their home, in the direction of Broadway, Westminster, and I saw them come back again in the space of half-an-hour—one of them, I cannot swear which, had a bundle about the size of a hat, or possibly smaller—it hung down from a handkerchief.
Crawley. Q. Did you see me go up and down stairs there? A. Yes.
Davis. Q. Can you swear you have seen me with the other prisonen within the last six weeks? A. Yes, decidedly I have, within the last month, with Crawley and Harris.

Dudley. He did not see anybody at my place on Monday morning; my brother came there by himself on Monday evening to bring his dirty linen, but no one was there to see me on Monday morning. Witness. I am sure I saw Crawley, Harris, and Davis at Dudley's on the Monday morning.

LOUISA EVANS . I am the wife of James Evans, and live at No. 9, Mint-street, Borough. About three weeks before I was examined before the Magistrate, the prisoner Wells came to my house in company with the prisoner Brown, after a room which I had empty at the time, at No. 7, Mint-street, which is opposite my house—she did not take it—she said she would call in the evening, but she did not—the backs of the houses in Mint-street adjoin Mr. Pigeon's distillery—I did not see the prisoners again till they were at Queen-square.

Wells. How can you say there was any male with me? I was by my
self; Brown was not with me; the room would not suit me. Witness. You did not say anything about the room, but Brown was with you—there was a person lodging at No. 7 at that time, and since they have been taken up she has gone away—she left last Saturday night—after I showed Wells the room, she walked up stairs to that person, whom they knew—I do not know when they went out—the room I showed them was in No. 7—both Brown and Wells went into the room—the person they seemed to be acquainted with was named Brookes, and lodged in the second-floor back
room—they both went into that room—when Brown was down stairs he called "Sarah," which was the name of Mrs. Brookes, and he and Wells then went up to her in that room—that back-room commands a view of Mr. Pigeon's distillery, and I should think they could get out of that window—I cannot tell on what day this was—I did not hear of the robbery for nearly three weeks afterwards—I do not know when the man who lived with Mrs. Brookes went away, for I did not know that he was gone—the woman left last Saturday—she did not pay me my rent before she went, nor did the man—they had lodged there since January.
Brown. I was not there, I was not in the house. Witness. I am quite
sure he was—I saw him at the bottom of the stairs, and he went into the woman's room afterwards.

SARAH MATILDA KENDALL
re-examined. These ear-ring tops and silk-handkerchiefs are mine, and were in the kitchen—nothing more of mine his been found—I know this pistol, it was on the premises on the night of the robbery.

Wells. These ear-rings I bought eighteen months ago of a person who used to work with me, and they have not been out of my ears for eighteen months—I gave the same account to Mr. Barefoot. Witness. I know them to be mine from their being mended in a particular way—one ear
ring top is shorter than the other, and I know them by that—there is no mark on the handkerchief, but it had been hemmed, and has been partly unhemmed—it was so before I lost it—I described it before I saw it at the police-office—I am quite sure it is mine, and the ear-rings too.

ANN HUDSON
re-examined. This bead purse is mine—I know it by a few beads in it which are a little discoloured, different to the white—there is a darker coloured bead intermixed—that was so when I lost it—I have not the least doubt of its being mine—I have had it twelve months—I bought it of a person who came to the door with laces—the beads are the same colour, and I am familiar with the appearance of it—this knife is mine—that and the purse were taken from a drawer on the night of the robbery—I cannot swear positively to the pistol, but I believe it to be the same—I have not the least doubt of the knife being mine, because the tip is ground off.

Crawley. I have nothing to say for myself; I wish to speak for Dudley, my sister; I bought the bead purse of a pedlar, took it home, and gave it to my sister for her kindness in washing my things; I never told her so much as where I bought it.
Brown's Defence. With respect to the handkerchief found on Wells' neck, I left it at her house in my hat hanging against the wall; I gave 1s. for it on the Wednesday morning.
Harris's Defence. This knife I gave 6d. for to a man that sells knives and forks in the street—the point was broken when I bought it.

Wells' Defence. These ear-tops I bought eighteen months ago, and they had never been out of my ears; the handkerchief now produced was left in Brown's hat hanging against the wall; not knowing whose it was, stolen or not stolen, I threw it across my neck, and Mr. Barefoot took it off.

Dudley's Defence. Last Monday fortnight my brother came to see me to bring me his dirty linen, and he gave me the bead purse; my reason for leaving my lodging was because I could not pay my rent; I had the money to do so, but it went to support my brother in prison, and the land
lady would not let me stop.

WILLIAM HUMPHREYS (police-constable M 127.) I produce a certificate of Harris's former conviction, which I obtained from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—I know him to be the person—I was present at his trial.

(Andrew Harvey, locksmith and bell-hanger, No. 84, Paul-street, Fins
bury-square; and Mary Ann Haseman, No. 4, John's-place, Bedford-square, Commercial-road, gave Brown a good character.)

CRAWLEY—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

HARRIS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.
See page 914.

WELLS—
GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Transported for Seven Years.

DUDLEY and DAVIS—
NOT GUILTY .

1105.
ROBERT CRAWLEY,
EDMUND BROWN,
THOMAS HARRIS , and
JOHN DAVIS were again indicted for
burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
James Piercey, at St. George Hanover-square, about three o'clock in the night of the 16th of February with intent to steal, and stealing therein, 1 fork, value 10s.; 1 spoon, value 5s.; 2 1/2 lbs. weight of cigars, value 1l.; 21 pence, 101 halfpence, and 6 farthings, his property; and that Davis had been before convicted of felony; to which

CRAWLEY pleaded
GUILTY .

BROWN pleaded
GUILTY .
Transported for Ten Years.

JAMES PIERCEY . I keep the White Horse public-house, St. George's-place, Knightsbridge, in the parish of St. George Hanover-square. I have a flap in the street which leads down into the cellar—it is a heavy flap, and requires two men to lift it—it was fastened with bolts, but I could not swear it was bolted on the night of the robbery—I was aroused about ten minutes before three o'clock in the morning of the 17th of February—I went down, and found Brown and Crawley in custody of two constables—the door leading to the cellar was open, and the bar-parlour door also—it had been picked and forced open—the cellar-door had a button to it—I lighted the gas, and found the till at the bar-counter half open—I missed all the halfpence, sixpences, fourpenny pieces, and a few farthings—I think there was about 5s. worth of halfpence—my desk was broken open, and a silver fork, a spoon, and a pair of spectacles gone, and almost every paper in the desk rummaged about—I missed a box of cigars from a closet—I went into the cellar with the constable, and found the halfpence, cigar-box, and crow-bar all behind a gin-cask, also a silver spoon and fork, some lucifer matches, and a piece of wax candle—the cellar-flap opens into the street—one of the bolts of that flap have been lost—there is a flight of stairs leading from the cellar to the bar—I had locked the bar-parlour door the previous evening—the knife produced is mine.

WILLIAM KENWARD . I am a private watchman in the barrack-yard, at the back of the prosecutor's house. On the morning of the 17th of February, soon after two o'clock, I saw five men at the top of the barrack yard close to the side of Mr. Piercey's—they were standing talking—I heard one of them say it was easily lifted up—they then went towards Wilton-place—about a quarter of an hour afterwards four of them re
turned, and stood a minute or two at the corner of the public-house where they had stood before—they then went round the corner to the front of the house, where the cellar-flap is—I heard them say, "Up with it, up with it, look sharp"—two crossed over, and sat on the railings of Hyde-park—I went up the yard, and looked at Mr. Piercey's door—the two who sat by the park went up towards Hyde-park-corner—I cannot say who they were I was not sufficiently close—I saw Twitchett following them—the park railing is about fifty yards from the house, just opposite the house—it is the width of the road—Twitchett came part of the way towards me—there was a screaming heard near Hyde-park-corner—he went there, and I waited at the cellar-flap to see that nobody came up until he returned—I then told him what I had heard, and waited while he went to look for the other two persons—he could not find them, but brought a policeman with him—they lifted up the flap, and went down—I waited outside—I afterwards found the prisoners in custody—the two persons had got about twice the width
of the road, when the constable came up—it was after I heard them say "Up with it," that the two separated themselves from the other two.

EZRA TWITCHETT (police-constable B 114.) About two o'clock in the morning of the 17th of February, I was passing along Park-side opposite St. George's-place, on duty, and saw the prisoners Harris and Davis there—the other two were on the other side of the way—I followed Harris and Davis to Hyde-park-corner, then proceeded down St. George's-place, and saw Crawley and Brown there, about three doors from the public-house—Harris and Davis were on the opposite side of the road, directly opposite the pro
secutor's house, when I first saw them—I afterwards saw Kenward—I returned to St. George's-place, and Kenward told me what he had seen—I went to see if I could find Harris and Davis, but I could not, and returned—I went down into the cellar, and heard somebody in the parlour—while I was in the cellar, Brown and Crawley came down from the parlour, and I took them—I found a quantity of things disturbed in the house—I and Upchurch apprehended Davis and Harris together at eleven o'clock next morning in the Broadway, Westminster—when we got to Queen-square we told them they were the persons who were in St. George's-place—they said they knew nothing of the other two prisoners, and that they were not in St. George's-place—I am certain I had seen them opposite the prosecutor's house that night—they are the two men who went from Park-side—they were exactly opposite the prosecutor's house—the first time I saw them was about one o'clock—they were then all four together.

WILLIAM UPCHURCH . I am a policeman. I was with Twitchett when he took Davis—he made a violent resistance—I took Harris—on the morn
ing of the day before I had seen Harris and Davis with Crawley, Brown, and another person in Orchard-street, Westminster, a few yards from Nos. 10 and 11, New Way-square—the knife the prosecutor has identified was found on Crawley.
JOHN VASEY . I live opposite Nos. 10 and 11, New Way-square. I have seen the four prisoners in both those houses, going from house to house—I have seen them all in company together frequently.
Harris's Defence. On the night this robbery was done I was at my sister's.

Davis's Defence. I am innocent of the charge; the other two prisoners know I was not with them; they took me in the Broadway, and almost choked me; I would not go; they caught hold of my collar, and I walked quietly afterwards.

EZRA TWITCHETT
re-examined. I have no doubt of Davis being one of the two.

JAMES BROOK (police-constable L 118.) I produce a certificate of Da
vis's former conviction, which I got from Mr. Clark's office—(read)—I was present at his trial—he was tried by the name of John Edwards—I know him to be the person, and knew him before.

HARRIS—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

DAVIS—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

1106.
JAMES HIDE was indicted
for stealing, on the 5th of February, 1 Pair of boots, value 7s., the goods of
John Bucknell.

JOHN BUCKNELL . I am a milkman, and live in George-street, Camber
well. I know the prisoner—he lodged in the same room with me for six
nights—on Sunday, the 6th of February, I missed a pair of boots, which were under the table at the foot of my bed—these now produced are mine.

RICHARD GILES . I am a policeman. I took the prisoner into custody on the 9th of February, but not on this charge—I searched him, and found a lot of duplicates on him, one relating to a pair of boots, which I have here—I went to the prosecutor and gave information, took him with me to the pawnbroker's, and he identified the boots—these are them.

CHARLES WATSON . I am a pawnbroker, at No. 20, Crossby-row, Wal
worth. These boots were pledged at my shop, in the name of Hide—I cannot swear to the prisoner, but it was such another person—this is the duplicate I gave to the person who pledged the boots.
GUILTY . Aged 19.

1107.
JAMES HIDE was again indicted
, for stealing, on the 9th of February, 1 ring, value 5s., the goods of
William Calvert Parkinson.

WILLIAM CALVERT PARKINSON . I am a sergeant of the 13th Light Dragoons, and live in Gardener's-lane. I employed the prisoner on the 9th of February, at my lodging, to mend some clothes for me in my room—I missed a ring that day from a trunk in my room, where I had placed it that morning—it was not locked—I charged the prisoner with taking it—he denied it—I told the corporal to fetch a policeman—he called the corporal back, and said he would show where the ring was—it was pro
duced by the policeman—this is it—it is mine, and is worth 5s.

JOSEPH EDWARDS . I am a corporal in the 13th Light Dragoons and lodge in the same house as Parkinson. On the 9th of February the pri
soner showed me where the ring was placed, which was in the window on the landing-place, out of the room—the policeman took it out in my pre
sence—the prisoner was not then present.

RICHARD GILES . I am a policeman. I was called in by Edwards—I took this ring from the window, where the corporal showed me—the pri
soner was not present—it was five pairs of stairs from the room the prisoner was in.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

1108.
JAMES GISSING and
JAMES LAIDLER were indicted for
breaking and entering the warehouse of
Timothy Richardson and another, on the 24th of February, at St. Olave, Southwark, and stealing therein, 38 sacks, value 5l.; 2 knives, value 4s.; their goods: and 2 jackets, value 4s.; and 1 knife, value 1s.; the goods of
David Cooper.
MR. CLARKSON conducted the Prosecution.

DAVID COOPER . I am warehouseman to Timothy Richardson and Son. I have examined the sacks produced by a policeman—they belong to them, and were in the warehouse on the evening of the 24th of February, at seven o'clock—when I shut up, I saw them safe—I secured the ware-house myself at that time—on the same evening, about nine o'clock, in consequence of information I received, I went to the warehouse, and met Laidler, about twenty or thirty yards from the warehouse, with a bundle of sacks upon his back—I stopped him, and asked where he was going with them—he said somebody had engaged him to carry them—I asked him to return to the warehouse—I took him back, and kept them till I got a policeman—I examined the warehouse, which is by the side of

the burial-ground, in the parish of St. Olave, Southwark, and found an upright bar forced away from the window looking into the burial-ground, which would enable a person to get in at the window—I missed thirty
eight sacks—I found sixteen on the prisoner Laidler—he was a stranger to us—the warehouse had been entered in the month of September be
fore and on that occasion we found a knife left behind, which we used afterwards to cut up the cat's victuals, and on the 24th of February, when we missed the sacks, we missed that knife—I lost two jackets and a clasp-knife of my own, which I have not seen since—this is the knife which was left at the warehouse in September—(produced)—these sacks are ours—here is a chalk mark of mine on them, and "G" in a diamond—they are all marked as our sacks are.

MARY PLANT . I am the wife of a hop-porter, and live in the Borough. On Thursday night, the 24th of February, at nine o'clock, I was near Mr. Richardson's warehouse, and heard the bar of the warehouse door drop inside, and at that time I saw the prisoner Gissing standing at the door, which was half open—I have known him five years—the door was shut very gently afterwards, and Gissing walked away towards the burial-ground—the door must have been closed by somebody inside—I gave information, and in about two minutes after, I went round to look for my little girl, and saw Gissing, I asked him if he had seen a girl pass with a white bonnet—he said, "No, ma'am"—I am positive he is the man.

JOHN JAMES BURR. I am a turner, and live in St. Mary's-court, Borough—Plant is a neighbour of mine—she met me at nine o'clock at night, and told me something, in consequence of which I watched the door of Mr. Richardson's warehouse, and saw the prisoner Laidler come out with a bundle of sacks upon his back—he passed by me—I saw two more come out of the warehouse almost at the same time, immediately after him, Laidler passed me, and went in a direction down Maze-pond—the two others crossed the road to a court opposite the gates of the prosecutor's warehouse—they went down the court, and I lost sight of them—I did not see them with any thing—I kept my eye on Laidler till Cooper stop
ped him.

SAMUEL MANLEY . I am a boot and shoemaker, and live at Maze
pond. Borough. About nine o'clock this night, I saw Gissing and Laidler opposite Mr. Richardson's warehouse, talking together—I knew Gissing Wore—I am sure Laidler is the man he was talking to—soon after, I saw Laidler coming down Maze-pond—Cooper stopped him with the sacks—this was about five minutes after I had seen the prisoners talking together—Laidler got away—there was a cry of "Stop thief"—I ran after him, and took hold of him—he knocked me down, and beat me severely about the loins—I still held him, and while I was down, Gissing ran by.

Gissing. It was nine o'clock at night—he said he was shutting up the shop, and saw this man in custody, and saw me run by—how could he swear to me at that time of night? Witness. There was a gas-light ex
actly at the corner where we were.
THOMAS BOLTON . I am a policeman. I took Laidler into custody, and found this knife in his pocket at the station.

THOMAS WATKING . I am a policeman. I received sixteen sacks at Mr. Richardson's warehouse, on the night of the 24th—I took Gissing into custody on the following Saturday, in Tooley-street—he asked what I wanted him for—I said, "For breaking into Mr. Richardson's ware-house"
—he said he knew nothing about it, that he was at the play he, had never been there at all.

MRS. PLANT re-examined. The door of the warehouse does not look into the burial-ground, but into Maze-pond—the window is twenty or twenty-five feet from the street, in which direction there is an iron railing parting the burial-ground from the street—Gissing was stand
ing at the door when I first saw him, and when I spoke to him, he was about twenty yards from the door—I did not see him come from within the house, nor from the burial-ground.
Gissing's Defence. I was coming from Dock-head, about half-past eight, or twenty minutes to nine o'clock, and it was about nine when I got to the Surrey Theatre, to meet some one there.
Laidler's Defence. I was standing in the Borough; a man came and asked whether I wanted a job; I said, "Yes;" he took me inside the warehouse and gave me the sacks.

GISSING—
GUILTY .* Aged 19.

LAIDLER—
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Ten Years.

1109.
JAMES KELLY and
JAMES YOUER were indicted for
felo
niously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
Henry Cookson, on the 22nd of February, at Rotherhithe, and stealing therein 1 coat, value 10s.; 2 pairs of trowsers, value 1l.; 1 jacket, value 5s.; 1 shirt, value 2s.; 4 handkerchiefs, value 35.; 1 waistcoat, value 2s.; and 1 petticoat, value 6d.; his goods.

JANE COOKSON . I am the wife of Henry Cookson, a labouring man, and live in Manor-lane, in the parish of Rotherhithe. On Tuesday, the 22nd of February, I left home at one o'clock in the day, leaving no one in the house—I locked the door—I am sure, for I tried the latch of the door, and put the key into my pocket—I came back about six in the evening, and found the door had been burst open—the latch that the lock goes into was broken off—I went into the house and missed a handkerchief from a bundle which was at one corner of my bed-room, and contained other things—I missed a jacket, trowsers, and shirt from the dirty linen—I gave an alarm, and went out into the yard—my husband fetched a policeman—I then missed a coat, waistcoat, and a pair of trowsers, three hand kerchiefs, and a petticoat' from a box in the bed-room—they were there when I went out—they were my husband's property—I saw part of them at a clothes-shop in Kent-street, on the Saturday, as I missed them on the Tuesday—(pro
duced)—this shirt belongs to a young man named George Harvey, whom I wash for—these trowsers and jacket are also his—this handkerchief be
longs to my husband.
Kelly. Q. What time was it when you left your house? A. One o'clock.

CHARLES POPE . I am in the employ of Mr. Hunt, a bone-factor, in Manor-lane. On Tuesday, the 22nd of February, I was standing in Mr. Hunt's yard, which is near the prosecutor's—he lives in the yard—he has a house there—I saw the prisoner Kelly go up to Cookson's house about four o'clock, and I saw Youer standing out in the lane, about ten yards from their house—I had known the prisoner Your for six or eight months, and Kelly about a month—Kelly was dressed in a blue jacket,
trowsers, and Youer in a fustian jacket and trowsers, and a green south-wester—I did not see them do any thing.

CHARHLES LEWIS . I am a labourer—I was employed in a yard near Mr. Hunt's—I know Cookson's house well. On Tuesday, the 22nd of February, about four o'clock in the afternoon, I was near there, and saw Kelly come from Cookson's house with a bundle under his arm, wrapped in a reddish handkerchief, and Yoeur was standing at the gate—they both went away in company.

RICHARD COLLINS . I am a shopman to Messrs. Wharton, pawnbrokers, No. 443, Bermondsey-street—I produce a coat, waistcoat, and trowsers, which I took in pledge on the 22nd of February from the prisoner Kelly—I did not know him before—I gave him a duplicate—I am sure he is the person.

MARY DAGO . I keep a clothes-shop at No. 284, Kent-street, Borough. On Tuesday, the 22nd of February, I purchased these boots, shirt, jacket, and handkerchiefs of Youer—I asked him what made him sell his clothes—he said he had been on the Croydon Railway at work, and had been three months out of work—the jacket was on his back, and the trowsers tied up in this handkerchief under his arm.

WILLIAM BOWER (police-constable M 202.) I took Youer into custody—I asked what he had done with the property—in consequence of what be told me I discovered some at Mrs. Dagg's, and the pawnbroker gave up the rest.
Youer. He has taken a false oath, I never told him where the property was.

Kelly's Defence. I was coming from St. Katherine's Dock and met a man with a bundle, he asked if I would pawn it for him, and he would give me a drop of drink—that was at half-past twelve o'clock or a quarter to one—I went and pawned them in the name of John Collins, and gave him the tickets—I knew nothing about their being stolen.

Youer's Defence. About half-past one o'clock I saw a lad come from the house, in a blue jacket, trowsers, and coat—he said, "Have you got any coat?"—I said "No"—he said, "I have been out of work three weeks and must pledge my clothes"—I said it was a bad job—he gave me the jacket to put on—I went first with that to Mrs. Dagg, who offered 1s. 6d. for it—I came out and told the lad—he said he would take it; and he gave me the other things to sell—he gave me something to drink.
(Ann Mowser, of No. 77, Paradise-street, Rotherbithe, gave Youer a good character.)

KELLY—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

YOUER—
GUILTY . Aged 19.
Transported for Ten Years.

1110.
JOHN HOWARD was indicted
for stealing, on the 16th of February, 1 bag, value 1s.; 2 napkins, value 1s.; 1 purse, value 6d.; 4 shillings, and 1 sixpence; the property of
Robert Bennett, from the person of
Eliza Bennett.

ELIZA BENNETT . I am the wife of Robert Bennett, who lives at Bat
tersea. About five o'clock in the afternoon of the 16th of February, I was on Clapham-common—the prisoner came up and accosted me with very goss language, not fit for a female to repeat—he followed me some distance, and then snatched from my arm my bag, which contained four shillings and sixpence and two cotton napkins—I can swear he is the

person who snatched it—he then said that was all he wanted—he ran and I cried out "Stop thief"—I lost sight of him; and in about twenty minutes he was brought to the station, and I saw him again—the bag was found and brought in afterwards—this is it—I have not the least doubt whatever about the prisoner being the man who snatched it from me.

ISAAC BARROW . I am a constable. On the 16th of February, about five o'clock in the afternoon, I saw the prisoner running with great speed across Clapham-common; Mrs. Bennett and others were crying "Stop thief" after him—I ran as fast as I could, but I found he was gaining ground very fast—I saw a servant on horseback, and requested him to ride after him and stop him—he ran and attempted to stop him, but he got down a lane—I went after him and found him in about three minutes.

WILLIAM BODDY . I am servant to Mr. Hankey, of Clapharn-common—I saw the prisoner walking by the side of the prosecutrix; and in a minute or two I saw him run from her with a bag in his hand—I heard her cry "Stop thief"—I am sure the prisoner is the person who ran away.
JAMES DAVIS . I picked up this bag about five o'clock, on Clapham-common, behind a tree—I took it to the station.
ROBERT EMMERSON (police-sergeant V 9.) I received this bag from Davis, and Mrs. Bennett identified it.

Prisoner's Defence. I was on the common with two more young men—I walked by the side of the prosecutrix, and she conversed with me a great way—a person snatched the bag—I called "Stop thief," but I was not the person who took it.
MRS. BENNETT re-examined. There was no one with him.

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined One Year.

1111.
JOHN ROLFE was indicted
for stealing, on the 9th of February, 70lbs. weight of lead, value 12s., the goods of
George Stevens, his master.

GEORGE STEVENS . I am a plumber, and live in Bermondsey-street—the prisoner was in my service for about fifteen months—on the 9th of February, early in the morning, I received information, I got up and saw a pig of lead standing in the passage by the side of my house—I waited and saw the prisoner come and take it up, and go off with it—be had no business with it—he was sent with another to clean the windows of the Deaf and Dumb Asylum—I followed, and when I came up to him be put it down and ran away—I secured, and took him to the shop, and he begged for mercy.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. How far had he carried it? A. About twenty yards—he asked me to forgive him for the sake of his family—he has a wife and eight children—he ran sixty or seventy yards—I had bought this pig of lead—I had twenty-nine in the shop.
CAROLINE HAWES . I saw the prisoner take away this lead.

GUILTY . Aged 43.—
Confined Six Months.

1112.
HENRY STANHOPE was indicted
for stealing, on the 14th of October, 1 ring, value 2l., the goods of
William Edward Gowland.

ELIZABETH HARRIETT GOWLAND . I am the wife of William Edward Gowland of Hertford-road, Vauxhall—he is in the Excise Office—I am acquainted with the family of the French's, who live in Bond-street, Vaux
hall—I took tea and spent the evening there on the 13th of October in

the front parlour—I had my rings on when I went there—I had occasion in the course of that afternoon, while there, to take my rings off, for the purpose of washing my hands up stairs—among others, I took off a pearl hoop ring—I returned into the parlour and put on what I supposed to be all the rings I had taken off—when I returned home that night I did not miss anything, but the next day I missed this pearl hoop ring, now pro
duced—I sent to Mr. French's to inquire about it—I am in the habit of constantly wearing this ring—it is worth about 2l.—it was the guard ring given me on my marriage.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You cannot positively swear where you lost it? A. I know I had it that day, and I know I lost it that day—I missed it the next morning—I had it on, the day I was at Mrs. French's, and I was no where else—t always wear it—I know I had it in the evening—I never took it off after I put it on—I took off my rings at Mrs. French's, but I do not remember taking off this particular ring.
COURT. Q. Was this the outside ring? A. Yes.

MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. You put on the rings that you took off to the best of your belief? A. Yes—after sitting there I walked home that night—I live about five minutes' walk from Mrs. French's—Mrs. and Miss French have known me about four years—Miss French taught my children—she knew me perfectly well, and I suppose she knew my ring—I do not know whether Mrs. French knew my ring—I seldom saw her—Miss French came to my house as governess—I visited Mrs. French perhaps two or three times—I had seen her frequently—she had been at my house, I cannot tell how many times—perhaps ten times—she had an opportunity of seeing my ring, but a guard ring is so usual to wear, that I should not suppose she noticed it—it is a common ring.
Q. Is there nothing remarkable about it? A. Yes, it has been taken in—I had never seen the prisoner—he had never seen my ring—he was not there the night I lost it.

MR. CLARKSON. Q. Are you at all conscious of having dropped the ring from your finger? A. I could not, it fitted so very tight—I had not tan to any body's house between the evening when I took it off at Mrs. French's and missing it the following morning—I know I put it on the morning that I went to Mrs. French's—I had not taken my rings off for the purpose of washing my fingers, or any other purpose of that sort before I went to Mrs. French's, but I took them off there—my infant was there, and I fancied she had knocked it down—there was no other place at which I could have dropped it—I took all my rings off in Mrs. French's parlour, with the exception of one diamond ring, and I put all on, as I supposed, that I took off.

ELIZA SARAH FRENCH . I am single, and live with my parents, in Bond-street, Vauxhall. I know the prisoner, and I know Mrs. Gowland—I remember, on the 13th of October, she drank tea at my mother's, in the front parlour—on the morning of the 14th I remember seeing the prisoner—I should think about ten o'clock—the parlour bad not been cleaned up at that time—I went into the parlour on being informed the prisoner was there—I found him there—my mother came into the room, and went out, and came back again—the prisoner on that occasion pro
duced this ring to me—(looking at it)—he asked me to try it on, and asked if it fitted me—I tried it on, and soon after my mamma entered the said to her, "See what a pretty ring Mr. Stanhope has given me"—after I left the room.

Q. In what capacity was Mr. Stanhope received at your house? A. He was paying his addresses to me—he represented himself to be a gen
tleman of 300l. a-year, with 9000l. in the funds—I saw him again on Sunday, the 17th of October, at our house, and afterwards we went to take tea at his house in Newton-terrace—when I was at his apartment I perceived him drawing the ring off my finger—I said to him, "what are you doing?"—he said, "Oh, I wish to get you another ring made, a diamond and ruby ring"—he said, "Don't be afraid, you shall have this again; I only wish to take it to the jeweller's to get you a better; you shall have this returned with the diamond and ruby ring"—I allowed him to take it on that representation—I never saw this ring again till the day he was at Union-hall—it was produced there—he never gave me the dia
mond and ruby ring, nor this one back.

Cross-examined. Q. You are a governess, are you? A. Yes—I was governess to Mrs. Gowland's children, and I have had other pupils—I am twenty-one years of age—I am sorry to say I met with the prisoner, and formed an acquaintance with him in an omnibus—I did not ask him to my house, upon my oath—I have no one who pays his addresses to me now—I know a Mr. Logan, as a friend—I knew him before I knew the prisoner—I, and my mamma, and my sister were out—there was a crowd, Mr. Logan very kindly offered to take us through the crowd, and this we became acquainted with him—he made no pretensions, but he called at our house occasionally.

Q. The prisoner called on you on the Sunday, and you went to his house, did you not go rather before your mamma? A. Yes, my mamma and papa were not quite ready, and the prisoner said we would walk on first—my papa came to the house afterwards, but he was not there when I went—I went with the prisoner, and went into the parlour—I swear I was never in his bed-room—I did not take tea in his bed-room.

Q. Did not you and mamma take tea in the prisoner's bed-room, and has he any other room in the house but that bed-room? A. Yes, he had—people do not generally take tea in the bed-room—my mamma had not come to the house when the prisoner took the ring off—upon my oath the ring was taken off in the parlour—I am quite sure of that—no one was present but the prisoner and me—the people of the house were Dot pre
sent—that parlour is a room of which the prisoner has the exclusive use—he and I were there perhaps half-an-hour before mamma came—I did not consider there was any impropriety in being alone with him, when I was to be united to him at Christmas—he got the ring away on that oc
casion—I am sure he has never given me the ruby ring since—I have never had it to this day, nor any other ring from him—he brought one to try on, but took it away again.

MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Were your father and mother aware that be was paying his addresses to you? A. Yes—he made the same represents
tions to them that he did to me—that he was the eldest son, and heir to an estate—I received his addresses with their full approbation and con
sent, believing his representation, and that every thing was right and proper—when I met with him in the omnibus, I had a parcel containing some books—I had been to take a German lesson—he entered into con
versation with me in the omnibus, and was telling me about foreign countries, and of his father's cruelty in wishing him to marry a young lady to whom he was not attached—when we got out, he said, "I hope

you will allow me to see you home"—I said, "Oh dear no, a servant will meet me," but I was a few minutes earlier than usual, and the servant had not come—the prisoner wished to go with me—I said I did not con
sider it was proper, I was obliged to him—I left him, and when I had gone two or three steps, I found he was running after me—he said he hoped I inspected him of nothing, that it was a gentlemanly act, and he did it out of pure kindness—I said I did not suspect him of any thing but kindness, and he went on till I met the servant—he still continued with me—I let him do so, as I thought he would think I suspected him of improper motives—he went with me to the house, but he did not go in, but before this he pretended he had fallen in love with me, and pretended to the purest morality and religion, and great kindness of character.

JAMES SHOWELL . I am in the service of Mr. Spink, of Gracechnrch-street, a pawnbroker.
